151256104.review: I put this game on my wishlist, because the picture of Onbu was really cute. It has a bit of a learning curve, but it doesn't take long to learn. It's a really interesting balance between managing a city builder, and taking care of a giant creature. Now that I have a good grasp of what I'm doing, I can just spend hours in one save. The music is very relaxing, and I love seeing how I can develop the village. There are a lot of ways to make the game harder, but you can also play the game as is, and just relax. 10/10.

151249317.review:
A true work of art, the soundtrack alone is great to listen to in itself either playing the game or just relaxing at home.  The game itself is quite flexible, from relaxing and peaceful but can also keep your mind working.  Sadly the only real problem one can have with the game is how limited it is in "capacity" currently.

  Keep in mind it is still relatively new, and the Devs work hard on it ceaselessly, you can truly tell how much this game means to them.  Storyline feels more like an extended tutorial than anything else, so far because the Devs are currently more focused on Content at the moment.

  At it's most difficult, the game can still be somewhat relaxing with a steady "rolling on" feel to it where the changing environments are constantly keeping you adapting your town back and forth based on what the current "biome" provides for survivability.

Above all else, the music is beautiful, relaxing, and very well done.

Despite being severely lacking in plot or storyline, this does tend to make the game quite short-lived. (can be beaten in a handful of hours by an experienced gamer.  
Overall i would highly recommend this game if you are looking for a fun, relaxing, engaging, and immersing game full of fun and quirky elements. I have restarted new games from nothing numerous times and am happy to say the game never truly loses it's charm even after you have experienced all it currently has to offer.

Make no mistake, the downvote is one of those "because steam doesn't have a neutral rating" situations. I absolutely adore this game, and everything about it. ...I however simply cannot recommend this game, not yet, not in its current state. 

Early Access is one thing but right now the game is barely beyond "proof of concept" stage. It's way too simplistic in mechanics, at times rather unfair with a difficulty spike of "Oh you picked the easiest choice but reached this arbitrary point on the map? What I was hoping for was a relaxed city building game where I could vibe with some 2D people and a dinosaur, but what I got was a game that forces you to play slowly, despite the world around you very rapidly becoming more dangerous. This game quickly became anxiety simulator. By the time I knew about, or could access buildings and jobs that would help me in the current biome, a different one with completely different requirements would be coming up. Never mind that the people all move at a snail's pace, even with paths. By the time a building gets constructed that might have been helpful, whatever people needed it would already be dead. And GOD FORBID you try to stop your dinosaur so you can adjust to your current environment, because the ground is probably more poisonous than the air so there go your people anyway! 
  There is no consistent or reliable method of getting more people. They don't seem to reproduce, so you're left waiting for the game to graciously hand you 3 poisoned and hungry wanderers that will die 3 days after arriving on your dinosaur's back because it took them that long to walk to the nearest anything that could've helped.

148036151.review:
The core game is very fun, but what holds it back from reaching its full potential and taking its place among building game masterpieces like frostpunk is the RNG.

If the second biome your  onbu walks in is a jungle, you all of your people die and you loose, no further questions.

I'm not saying there should be no RNG in this game at all. Frostpunk has RNG deciding who falls sick, and it's still a perfect game. The difference is that RNG needs to be applied in big numbers, making it predictable.

For Example, I don't have a problem with the RNG in the wandering Village that decides who get's poisoned, because I know that if I have 15 people in certain housing and at a certain workplace, 5 to 7 of them are gonna fall sick. The fact that the RNG is applied not just once, but 15 times, is what makes it predictable.

That's what's missing from the Onbu and Map RNG. If your onbu walks into a wrong biome early in the game, or if you have a hornblower but there just is no good biome to walk into, that RNG is applied only once, meaning I have no chance to predict it, and that in combination with the fact that being unlucky can destroy your entire run makes it very frustrating to play.

Honestly, I don't know how I would go about fixing this, I have the privilege of being a player that can complain in the comments without having to find a solution. But if you fix this, if you find a way to remove RNG where it can't be predicted, then your game will be among the building game greats.

147822879.review:
I hate to downvote a game this cute, but to be honest, I was surprised about all the upvotes it's getting. The gimmick of building a city on the back of the six legged turtle is a fun idea, but it really has almost no actual gameplay impact - the world map seems interesting at first, but it surves no real purpose and doesn't really add much to the game due to everything being so random and so repetitive. If there was a larger view, maybe you'd have to think and consider going to a forrest for a few years or something like that, but the way it's now it's just 'pick the path that doesn't lead to a biome that will hurt your people' and that's it. Any interaction with the overworld also quickly turns into a mindless chore - send out endless exploring parties who with almost zero interaction return with resources you don't really care about and repeat, over and over.

That would be fine if it was an aspect of an otherwise good city builder, but that's just it - the base game is not a good city builder. It gets the mechanics right, but its like a soulless bureocrat was told about city builders and designed one - gather wood, gather stone, build homes, gather food, get more people, build farms, improve wood and stone, research better buildings. If someone held a gun to your head and forced you to come up with the most generic city builder, this is what would come out. None of it is done badly, it's just very bland and in no aspect have I seen anything inventive or interesting to set it apart from other games in the genre.

At $5 I would probably still have been left somewhat disappointed. It is by no means a bad game, just also not a good one.

I just love this game, it's fun and pretty and you can see the passion the devs put into it.

The gameplay isn't anything you haven't seen before in terms of colony sims, however taking care of the onbu and fostering the relationship between your people and the onbu was something new to me and it adds some interesting choices in terms of upgrade paths in the tech tree. In addition, onbu's movement on the map as a bigger picture type of situation adds a whole other dimension to game which makes it quite interesting, as you have to take outside influences into account while being able to circumvent some of those by paying attention and directing onbu to avoid say a sandstorm.
Nonehteless, the gameplay is not too complex and the wandering village is a rather relaxing title to be enjoyed after a day of work, all ther while a little more complex than some of it's genre competitors. 146100799.review:
[h1] A wonderful City Building Roguelike! [/h1]
The visuals are nice, the soundtrack is amazing, and the gameplay is addictive!
I have been playing this game since the early demos and betas, and I have nothing but positive things to say about it. The game in it's demo state was fantastic, and since the early days it has consistently gotten better, and now that the game came out the updates have kept rolling in. There has yet to be an addition that was unworthy. I received the game in a contest when it came out, but I DEFINITELY would have spent full price money on it!

The game is a twist on a city builder that feels like a hybrid mix with a rogue-like. Every settlement you build on Onbu teaches you something new.  [spoiler] First, my people starved. Second game I focused on food production so I got further, but Onbu succumbed to poison...[/spoiler] I won't spoil any more of my discoveries I've faced through my various towns, but you get the idea. Over time you learn how to make your next city better. How to space things out more efficiently. All these gameplay elements are very rewarding, and I find that this game has something similar going for it as Civilisation's "One More Turn-itis" where you basically just NEVER want to step away from your game!

BTW if Roguelike isn't your thing, you can also play it in various sandbox modes without deaths, which should be fun if that's your speed.

Pull up to right now, and my thoughts on the game were still, meh? I haven't played it again. I don't really want to. It didn't grab me the first time, and I have a feeling - despite being unique and kind of pretty - it isn't going to grab me at all if I give it another shot.
This will be a pass from me, but if you're adventurous and it's on sale, give it a shot. You may enjoy it, or you may be like me - "Meh". Don't forget about the 2 hour refund timer, just in case you don't fall in love with it.

Cute and fun! It's compelling and there's a lot to do, even though I can see places where there is still room to grow. It's a great resource management game, with enough actions to maintain that it doesnt slow down too much. I like checking the map for icons and the availability of new settlers/nomads. It is tough to balance new resources with changing environments, but not taxing or impossible. Definitely would recommend to anyone who likes idle/resource management and semi-casual city builders. 
In the future, I'd love to see a connecting thread or storyline, such as events that occur based on total miles traveled, or a larger map that tracks progress/biomes discovered. It would also be really cool to see more ways to craft resources or generate resources, perhaps a trade/transmutation system where you can turn certain crops/raw material into others or sell them to passing settlements. I think it would also be really cute to be able to interact with the ondu, such as an upgrade that gives them a colorful harness or jewelry etc. I was so happy when I unlocked the ability to pet them, but it isnt clear if there's a way to check trust level. 
Overall, I'm really enjoying it so far!

145684327.review:
Greetings as always!  I played the demo of “The Wandering Village” sometime ago and have been waiting to purchase it after some development.  I truly enjoyed this game but always have concerns about the content of any early access game.  Were my concerns founded?  Let’s Discuss!

On the backs of Giants:  At a quick glance this is a typical city builder, albeit with a very unique art style.  You gather resources, build housing and prepare food and even research newer and more efficient ways of doing these things.  You do have to mitigate the toxin that will poison (and kill) your populous but more on that in a moment.  The art style adds to the unique nature of this game too, a cell shaded 2.5d style that gives the game a unique character and a timeless nature.  The music is also very enjoyable and even my podcast heavy ears stopped to listen to the different tracks throughout my journey.  So, what we have so far is a typical city buider with great music.  Well, that all changes when you meet your best friend, the Onbu.

Bestest Boy:  The game truly becomes unique when you meet your greatest companion and walking island, the Onbu.  A giant creature big enough to transport your entire civilization and supply materials for your beginnings but more importantly allows your civilization go where the resources are.  Creating a never ending traveling city, one that not only provides but must be provided for.  You need to establish trust (or servitude) for your Onbu, guiding it from biome to biome, feeding, resting and treating any toxins or illness that it gets.  Onbu doesn’t always do what you want and sometimes makes decisions that not only hurt it but also your people.  You can ‘force’ it do what you want and even harm it for resources but I could not push myself to even try these devices, not for my loyal Onbu (maybe that’s the dog person in me).

Loyalty is Earned:  There are some issues with the game, resource management being one of them.  I would like to see filters and customized organization for each resource group.  I’d also like to know the trending and production of each of my resources.  Finally, it would be really helpful if you could create limits (both bottom and top) for resources, too many times I ate my final fish that should have been used to grow more fish.  Speaking of, I understand biomes have to change things up to keep you on your toes but if what is planted is going to just decompose why can’t I just tell them to stop growing kelp until the temperature goes down?  It is a bit to micro, which I don’t mind micro but unnecessarily so.  I will also say that scavenging is more or less the same, at a certain point I should be able to somewhat automate the process.  Finally, I will say that collapsing structures is a bit annoying and might need to be toned down a bit.

Playing this game gave me actual joy, from watching the Unbu’s head swaying, which I decided was it being happy, to the occasional tail wagging this game put a smile on my face.  I cannot, for the life of me, understand how anyone could harm this precious creature and I actually felt an attachment to my digital friend.  I’ve had my fill of the game but will definitely come back when there have been some additions to the content.  I can’t recommend this game enough if you are a city builder fan!  Enjoy!

145557393.review:
This game is fantastic as it is but also full of potential for more. There are some approaches to gameplay I didn't care for, but the moments of triumph made it worth it and difficult to put down. At the core of this game's appeal for me is Onbu- a dynamic character whose back doubles as the canvas by which you'll be designing your village. Watching them go from untrusting and uncooperative to trusting, gleeful, and thriving is satisfying. Their behaviors, animations, and just the whole nature of the character is reminiscent of Trico from The Last Guardian- a grand beast to get to know and want to protect. Traveling through the world's map is an exercise in protecting Onbu and assessing hunger and sleep levels.

I'm the type who likes building things. Designing towns and watching the inhabitants enjoy life and improve over time. Anno, Against The Storm, and the Two Point series are some of my favorites. I also like structured play with clear cut goals to work toward. The Wandering Village does have all of those things but there is a marked preference toward survival.

Weather effects can call for drastic changes to the inner workings of your village. Food can become scarce in a flash. So can water. Knowing when to have Onbu run through dangerous areas or circumstances is key. There are so many little things to pay attention to and small errors to make that carry big consequences. Many players will love that but the cute exterior and beautifully rest-inducing, zen-like music can set up different expectations. I found myself saving often lest some painful developments over as little as a ten-day period render my village empty and desolate. The auto saves are numerous though.

Eventually, I got the hang of things and played smarter. When it clicks, it really clicks and is so rewarding to play. The population grows, resources are abundant, and even Onbu does a cheerful jig as things are going well. Failure is a teachable moment. But I think people who are chiefly interested in a survival sandbox will find this title more enthralling.

My hopes for the future would be as follows. Here are some things I would like to see.

- A sprawling campaign- something like the tutorial but long form and involved with more frequent actions to take. This game is a sandbox and I think it could be that while also offering opportunities for people who enjoy finishing a bunch of objectives. More events. More random things to have happen on the world map.

- Easy mode for lazy and forgetful, accident-prone players. (e.g. myself) the tutorial doesn't elaborate on every single button at some point throughout and probably should.

- Little things to do during "downtime." Perhaps the townspeople could have requests or preferences. There are too many moments where I was waiting for resources to finish being prepared or researched topics to reach 100%.

Overall, a hearty thumbs up for how much fun the 7-8 hours I've played have been. Looking forward to seeing what additions may come into play as this title develops and/or leaves Early Access.

145545399.review: This game is fun but players are given too little control over aspects needed to progress. Knowledge points and new settlers are only available sporadically, and without them you cannot move forward. Certain key resources are only available in certain regions, but frequency and duration in those regions is outside of the players control. Medicine can only be grown in certain climates, but if the series of climates you are placed into are not favorable for medicine production, you may lose huge portions of your colony in a matter of minutes and which will take hours to get back. Overall a game with a relatively low reward system and unfavorable mechanics.

145408680.developer_response:
Hi -Vincent

Thanks a lot for this report. This sounds like an isolated case, since we have not received this exact report from any other players.

To find out why this is happening to you, we need your crash logs: After! the game crashes, please send us your crashlog file with your system specifications to our email address ( support@strayfawnstudio.com )

Here's how to locate the files:

Windows
- In the Windows Explorer, go to view and tick the box to show hidden files
- Navigate to C:\Users\Username\AppData\LocalLow\Stray Fawn Studio\The Wandering Village
- Inside this folder is the "Player.log" which is the logfile

Mac and Linux
For Mac and Linux the paths to the saves and logfiles looks like this:
- Mac: ~/Library/Application Support/com.strayfawnstudio.thewanderingvillage
- Linux: ~/.config/unity3d/Stray Fawn Studio/The Wandering Village

We would love to help, but without more information from you that's unfortunately not possible.

Also, just in case: Please restart your computer before trying to play the game again.

Thanks for your help and cheers,
Markus

I love this game!! I bought it around when it came out and even in such early access was obsessed. Onbu is an adorable lil guy :) The graphics are great, I love that you can zoom in super close and watch your villagers work. I think I may remember it being harder before, but currently playing on easy mode has been a pretty chill experience. I haven't tried it with hostility modifiers or harder difficulties yet, because I prefer to just relax, but I sense it would add a lot more to the game if that's what you're looking for. I love that there's plenty more buildings and research than before, because that was the only way I felt it was lacking. It's similar for me to a lot of games like prison architect but way more chill. I actually like that all the villagers are the same and I don't have to spend a long time making sure I have every person assigned to the most efficient building, that takes a lot of the relaxing out of games for me. 

All in all, fantastic game. Devs should be really proud of themselves. I'd recommend this game to anyone looking for a cute, relaxing, village building game. The only things I'd suggest is a way to assign or block specific villagers from specific buildings. My farm stand worker continues to run across the entire continent to grab some food instead of going to the kitchen next door lol. Also, the elder's guide could use way more information, it's not really helpful at all. (The game is pretty easy to understand, but there are some things I was trying to figure out and the elders guide didn't help)

I'm generally not a fan of survival city builder simulators, but I love this one: it does not overwhelm you with intimate interaction with every detail of every inhabitant, instead asking you to quickly overturn your survival strategy to adapt to the changing biomes and events.
Personally, I enjoyed it all the way. If you like simple, comprehensible mechanics with plenty of fine-tuning options and immersive gameplay where every choice can lead to your doom, the game is sure to be great for you as well.

I started in tutorial mode and I'm still struggling. I've played civilization and other more strategy-based longer play games and do not have any issue. I think my biggest problem is the resources. Like any game and IRL, there are never enough resources. I (maybe?) made the mistake of clearing a lot of my trees early bc of a poisonous fog and I just fully couldn't find the poison spots bc of all the trees and now I'm on day 66 struggling to do anything bc I don't have any wood. I have a sawmill and nursery (researching the forester) but nearly every in game day onbu breaks my sawmill (and my air wells) so I'm using more wood to fix the thing to get me the already extremely limited resource. I'm doing the scavenger exploration to every wooded area I can find to try to help but its just never enough. 

While wood is my biggest issue in this play through, its not the only issue. Water is also apparently impossible to find.... IN THE OCEAN. How in the world is the air dry on water?? C'mon now. I'm sure this is built in for the mechanic of using the sea-water based functions (not super sure again only 66 days in). And again, when Onbu breaks my darn air wells every day that makes collecting the resource even harder bc it will be down for so long due to lack of resources.

But honestly if they just tuned the breaking of buildings to be less frequent I probably would not be complaining but I buy a game to have fun and at this point it's just not enjoyable.

I think the only things different I've done in this run versus the first two is not really mess with Onbu at all (no bile or blood things and minimal feeding/guidance). Leaving review as still not recommended for the simple fact of how the tutorial went.

143997115.review:
I'd never played a city builder before this game because I've always been afraid I'd find them boring... the concept of The Wandering Village swayed me and opened my mind to a whole new genre, so I'm very thankful I decided to take a leap of faith! 

When it comes to the game itself, it's absolutely gorgeous - although I will admit that after a while (I'm a little over 350 days on my one successful attempt) it does get repetitive, so I'm hoping there will be a bit more content added as we go along, just to spice things up. 

Aside from the loop, I think this is a beautiful game. It's very easy to understand if you're new to the genre, and I found  it quite easy to manage with a little trial and error. I like the challenge of having limited space where to build everything, as it made me feel less overwhelmed (even though it becomes difficult to place buildings as you go along). Onbu feels like a real character instead of just a means of transportation, and I'm happy there's so many structures and features dedicated to it.

If you're new to the genre, and would like to try out city builders - or even if you just want to try something different in the genre - I definitely recommend this one!

143677607.review:
So far the Wandering Village has been fun. There's definitely a few mechanics to learn and get good at.

I do however think that it still needs some balancing to its economy, resources, number of villagers you encounter on your way and some villager AI tweaks.

For example, a game requires you to build a few essential buildings in order to prevent poison from spreading when you walk through the poisonous clouds & forests. You do however need to research a few buildings and then craft more resources to then build those other buildings. Depending on how lucky you end up at the start of your run, you might not even manage to build those essential buildings.

I'd either like to see those poisonous areas appear much later during the start of the run or tweak the amount of resources required to build those buildings faster / sooner.

The number of villagers you meet during the run is a little bit low, I’d say as farming alone requires a lot of (maybe even too many) people to keep everyone fed & store some food as well when you enter areas with different climates. Also, when you’re in arid zones, the cactus produces too little water and too slowly. Both of my runs basically were ruined even though I had two full farms producing the cacti. Or perhaps the villagers just eat way too much.

As for the villagers overall, I do feel like they get a bit confused when they’re assigned to take care of multiple things in a row. They start building a portion of the road, then go to finish the building, then harvest and many days later I have to ping them to finish the portion of the road they had started building.

Overall, there’s some very solid foundation for a city builder but it does need some tweaking in my opinion. I still would recommend picking this one up if you’re up for another city builder game!

143568906.review:
In a world where giant creatures still roam the earth, one mayor has a vision: build a village on the back of a giant beast. But first, he must deal with the demands of his whiny decor-loving villagers, who are never satisfied with just berries. He must also face the distrust of the dinosaur, who doesn't appreciate being mined, blood-sucked and micro-managed. 

The town must also survive the dangers of heatwaves, tornadoes, social distancing and poison clouds? Yes, and it is spewing out deadly spores, they won't Last of Us on you, but your laborers will drop like flies and turn your dino into a fossil. The Wandering Village will test your: graveyard-shift-managing skills, your patience to 4X speed, and your sanity believing this behemoth can float on water with those tiny legs.

143398837.review:
An interesting take on the city builder/survival genre with beautiful artwork and excellent music. I played for 100 hours before burning out, completing novice, adept and veteran levels (twice on the latter) and greatly enjoyed the experience ('just one more turn' players beware). Difficulty levels are distinct; I had a lot harder time on the harder difficulties, while novice was far too easy for me personally.

The UI is nicely laid out with a great set of options for choosing deletion, repairs and priorities of buildings, and plenty of feedback from the village itself. The tech tree has decent content (though I did not bother with the harmful buildings) and there are a decent amount of resources to acquire (more complexity would be nice but I get it's not that kind of game).

The gameplay loop itself is relatively simple and will eventually get samey, but that's to be expected. Each playthrough is nonetheless unique due to the randomised biomes and options you can take, in addition to the hostility modifiers you can add.

The only downsides I can think of are that the food stands are very inefficient and I do feel like the people eat too much (especially during a spore outbreak where they should be dropping everything to get the emergency sorted, not going for food after every plant picked/burnt). A rationing and emergency system would be nice to have (at the cost of susceptibility to poisoning perhaps).

7.5/10, full price is reasonable though I would always recommend sales anyway.

I would love to be able to recommend this game, I really would. I think the setting is great and the art style is easy to like. However, there isn't really much of a game here. The tech tree is limited, the biomes repetitive (and really don't have much effect on gameplay), and resources are comically restricted (you get three logs from a tree, it costs five logs to make a tent!). Most of the time, you are simply waiting for resources to regrow or for more people to randomly turn up so you can use the buildings you have unlocked. The workaround for this seems to be constant micromanagement of buildings, switching on and off as required, which is not a rewarding gameplay loop. Farms use all of your water and barely produce any food (most of which gets eaten by hungry villagers long before your useless workers take it to the kitchen, where it will be helpfully turned into less food. 
In short, a great concept with a load of potential, but the devs really need to figure out what they are trying to make and focus on that.

I'm leaving a positive review despite not being able to honestly recommend the game in it's current state. That being said, it would be unfair to give it a negative review since the game has a lot of potential and it's still in early access.

The graphics is nice and the music is acceptable I guess (didn't pay much attention to it). What the game lacks is content. There should be more of everything - technologies, buildings, biomes, resources. Late-game is pretty much non-existant and the game becomes quite repetitive after you've seen all biomes (which usually occurs around 30th day, while the game is designed to last for 100+ days). I got quite bored with the game after discovering all major techs and finding out there's nothing more to do and there's nothing that threatens my settlement anymore (around day 120 or ~8 hours of gameplay). I will give this game another chance in a year or so when there would hopefully be more content.

142926011.review:
A Charming Twist on City Building! "The Wandering Village" offers a refreshing take on the city-building genre with the lovable Onbu companion. Taking care of this creature and building a strong bond along the way adds a delightful dimension to the gameplay.

While the game doesn't provide an extensive amount of space like "Cities: Skylines," it offers more than enough room to create a thriving and satisfying colony, even in the endgame.

One aspect I particularly enjoyed was the strategic placement of certain buildings, adding a touch of challenge and fun during the construction process.

"The Wandering Village" provides a tranquil experience, filled with pleasant events and diverse biomes to explore, making it a truly relaxing and enjoyable journey.

The game's active development gives me great optimism for its future, and I'm excited to see what new features and content will be added.

Although the graphics may not reach god-tier levels, they are still good and contribute to the game's overall charm.

As you progress into the endgame, you may notice some repetitive elements, but there's still plenty of fun and engaging activities to keep you entertained until that time.

In conclusion, "The Wandering Village" is a delightful indie game that stands out with its unique city-building mechanics, charming visuals, and tranquil atmosphere. If you're a fan of city-building games with a twist, this one is worth exploring!

I have been playing for less than an hour but the potential here is absolutely enough to write a review! Maybe not from the graphic and resource management part this game has been the closest thing to the well known game, Banish. Not by the playing way but by the way it compliments the missing parts of Banished.

The game itself start really fast and you need to build up as fast as you can. So I'm not gonna start talking about the games standard features like farming, herb collecting, stone collecting etc. The main difference is you don't need to build a building for the basic resources like mini stones and simple trees. But for other, for advance management you need to build-up.

The tech tree is the most important improvement in my opinion. Many of the games have these kind of tech trees but this one is simple yet very efficient.
Idea of a moving village instead of events coming to you is interesting and engaging. You have to be ready for literally everything from everywhere without any forecasts.

Game itself is really engaging and will love to explore more about it!

142781120.review:
My new favorite city builder. Let me tell you how this game sticks to the mold before I tell you how it's breaks it. 

City Builders are all the same.  Build a farm for food, build a warehouse to store goods, etc.  There is nothing incredibly new in this game.  You have individual citizens which you see marching all over, but they don't have names or personalities, they don't go crazy.  This isn't RimWorld.  Wandering Village is a survival builder, with limited resources and dying villagers, but nothing as serious as Frostpunk or Banished. I normally don't like survival builders but this game I don't mind.  That's because of the "Wandering" part.  

What the Wandering Village adds is a moving "pet" that your settlement rests upon. This has more personality then a game like Airborne Kingdom.  The pet mechanic allows you a map to see what biomes and weather are ahead of you, allows you to scout out in the world for resources, and gives you limited choices in what direction to go in.  Basically, you can plan ahead for some disasters, and there is more variety to the disasters then just "winter" and predictable cycle of seasons.  You also build a relationship with your pet, giving you some control over what he does, but you also live off the things growing on his back, and eventually you will need to become parasites, digging into his flesh for resources needed to weather the toughest biomes, so it becomes a balancing act.  

All this is contained in a rather chill game.  The art style is highly reminiscent of Studio Ghibli's film "Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind."  The controls are already fantastic for a early access game, and I will be playing this on console when it's released.

142771134.review: This is one of those rare gems of a game that I picked up in early access, and it's excellent AND they're continuing to make it better with regularity. I can't wait to see what it becomes, because it's already fantastic.

142750042.review:
8/10 A cute and engaging management sim.

Set firmly in the world of Hayao Miyazaki's "Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind", you manage a small settlement built atop a lumbering beast named Onbu (literally "Piggyback" in Japanese). Your town must survive against poisonous spores, famine, and numerous environmental hazards in a post apocalyptic world slowly being devoured by nature. On easy settings, it is a fairly chill game, but on the more difficult settings, one mistake can easily spell ruin for both your townsfolk and the poor, brainless beast of burden you live upon.

There is no story, which is fine. All you do is try to survive day after day as you grow your village to make it more self-sustainable. With most similar games, there comes a point where the town is large and strong enough to weather any calamity, but in this game, you have to stay alert well into the endgame. This is what makes The Wandering Village so enjoyable: There's always something that must be done to keep your settlement from collapsing. And while there's no specific end goal beyond aimlessly traveling the world, the game is engaging enough that the journey itself is the point.

All in all, a solid, highly enjoyable experience.

142726055.review:
I guess my problem is I'm not sure what this game is trying to be. As a city builder/management sim it's really shallow (everything basically boils down to "what crop am I growing for the next 10 minutes"). There's not really a major story-telling aspect aside from the initial "world is toxic" setting. The idea of a city building a symbiotic relationship with this titan (onbu) is a super neat idea, but...

At the same time it's also very shallow. Get a horn, feed it once or twice, and it will basically do most anything you tell it to. And there's no punishment (that i found) for doing the "anti-onbu" things aside from it basically ignoring your orders. Which ultimately doesn't really matter, because the city management is shallow enough that minimal planning is needed to prep for the next biome you're entering, and you would likely have had to make those preparations anyway. The only time I actually directed my onbu was when I wanted to figure out what was in a biome I hadn't been in yet. 98% of the time I just let it walk.

If you like simple and soothing city builder games, this game prolly isn't a bad pickup. If you were hoping this had a bit more strategy involved or the relationship with the titan was more impactful, at this point in time (7/24/23) I can't really say you'll have fun with this game. You'll likely be like me and get a handful of hours of trying things out and then be done.
142726055.developer_response:
Hi RanchSmoothie

Thanks a lot for the feedback! The Wandering Village definitely wants to be a game in which the symbiosis between the creature and the people are key, so we totally agree with you there :)

We think we're on a good stable foundation now, as lots of people enjoy the current state of bonding with Onbu. But we're only just at the start and this is something we definitely have big plans on how to improve. While we have some villager updates upcoming next, Onbu will be the focus after that.

If you think that the game is too easy and you can breeze through it, I would like to highlight the "Hostility Modifier System". If you enable some of those, then you really have to be swift and clever and plan ahead to keep the villagers and Onbu alive. Especially on the higher levels, it's really tricky and people in the discord are exchanging strategies on how to beat it.

More in-depth stuff is definitely coming. If you get around to test the hostility modifiers, I would love to hear back if this added challenge works for you.

Thanks and cheers,
Markus

142643937.review:
TL;DR: S'alright. Design issues and lack of content. Will recommend if it improves. I really want it to.



The art is very appealing and the setting is AMAZING with so many unique possibilities. Unfortunately though I can't recommend it. Fair enough I got almost 8 hours out of it but with colony sims I really expect something more. And it wasn't necessarily a memorable 8 hours. 

I blew through more or less the whole tech tree and I never really broke a sweat. I played on the normal difficulty and I could switch to a harder difficulty, sure, but I feel like I already saw everything there is to see and it became very repetitive.

Gripes:
-Scavenging is annoying micro management more than interesting decision making
-No reason not to play on max speed
-A lot of the buildings you just toggle on when you need them and toggle off immediately after if you want to play optimally. Or just leave them manned and idle because you can't be bothered anymore.
-Biomes are rather short lived and repetitive
-Biomes don't actually change the way you play. You just switch some crops around if you walk into a desert, and it's sad to see the core premise of a wandering village be solved by three or four mouse clicks once an hour.
-Exclusively the ocean biome has unique tech for it that is only usable in the ocean biome. No other biome is like that. It's weird.
-No events really caused any worry or concern 
-Most difficult part of the game was finding a spot to place my big end game decoration
-Nothing shocking or surprising happened in the play through. You know... some dwarf fortress style "FUN"
-No choices to make a run unique. I guess I can choose to be cruel to the animal or not but regardless I will still need to heal it, cure it and pet it and then harvest it's blood for food variety and it's bile for fighting the poison.

Again, I love the art and setting, there is so much potential. Just needs to work out some design issues and add a lot more content. I am looking forward to changing my review.

It's nice, especially the art. But the game is too easy. I was expecting on Adept to have more challenging events, and more of a depair feeling. I will try it on the hardest difficulty, but something tells me that not much will change.
If you have steady income of resources, it's almost impossible for you to lose. Game is very forgiving. I even got the achievent for not feeding Onbu more than 3 times within 100 days. This achievement is actually quite random, which might  be irritating for people trying to get it. Later in the game there were literally no feeding plots for Onbu.
So, my recommendation - balance the game. Do not make it completely random. Place shrines every N kilometers. Feeding spots, that you can reach to, that you will know about, not somewhere inside the fog-of-war. You can just place there more obstacles, more dangerous events.
Also, tornadoes are just irritating. Especially the fact that they are not disappearing. But you can make them unavoidable, going along the road, or at any direction at all, like whirlpools do. It will feel more realistic.
Same for poisonous clouds and mushroom forests, there are too many of them and they do too little. Couple of herbalists and doctor buildings solved everything that I was meeting on the road. Even couple of times Onbu was sleeping right in the forest. I didn't even bother to wake it up to leave the forest.
I would recommend the game, but may be much later, when there will be more content, when it will be balanced better and have more challenges.

142560002.developer_response:
Hi s0ur lem0ns

Thanks for the feedback! Can you go into more detail what doesn't work in the tutorial for you? We improved the tutorial together with the community and got very positive feedback for it so far.

The game should be responsive and the tutorial should work. Can you tell me which system specs you have so we can see if there's need for improvement? If you're on a lower end system, in the options, please disable Antialiasing, lower screen resolution and texture resolution. This should let the game run on most computers. Also, if your inputs are not sensitive enough, we have options for this as well so you can increase sensitivity if for example the mouse scrolling is too slow/fast or keyboard movement is too slow.

In the tutorial:
For scrolling, use the mouse wheel or the shortcuts 4,5,6 to choose between the different zoom levels. With 1,2,3 and space you can modify timing/speed/pause. WASD or click and drag on the floor to move the camera. Click on the "Elder's Notebook" button in the top right corner to continue the tutorial if you missed it. With these things you're equipped to play the game :)

If you need more info or have additional feedback, please let me know.

Thanks and cheers,
Markus

142503158.review: I was reached out to by the studio Stray Fawn to test their game. I had remembered seeing a trailer for it and being interested off that alone. I LOVE city builders with a little bit MORE? I grew up on Roller Coaster Tycoon and have always been chasing that high and let me tell YOU. This game DOES it. It was fun, well organized, smooth, BEAUTIFUL. It was so easy to figure out while simultaneously giving you that building strategy you need. AND YOU GET TO RIDE AND FEED A GIANT CREATURE. What could be better? I really loved the mechanics and I am now fully addicted. I did my blind react and play test on my YouTube Channel (ClockworkAngel). 20/10. Thank you so much Stray Fawn for reaching out to me and providing codes for me to give to my community. I hope to work with you again.

142502814.review:
The good:
I enjoy the limited story that is there
Onbu is very cute
there is quite a lot to manage for those that like that
the city building changes nearly every run with different configurations of onbu

The meh:
you are permanently locked into a 45 degree angle view which doesn't really feel great
It feels like villagers actively ignore priority, in my playtime I did NOT see any change from getting things built no matter the priority, though this could be because I was not great at managing them

The bad:
the first run feels cool because you are seeing everything for the first time but repeat runs with modifiers certainly feel samey, with the fact that events dont change based on difficulty(did two runs, easy and normal mode), the limited number of events also dont help this problem
A lot of the playtime is spent waiting, wether it be for resources to grow, building to be built, or just waiting for 500Km to finish a run
Villagers often waste raw resources to refine them even when not needed and you cant set a limit for them to stop refining

Overall:
I think the game is good for the people that already enjoy city builders, for those that don't I would say probably either wait for more content or pass on it, as it stands I enjoyed my first run but by about hour 3 I was realizing the monotony that comes with just adding farms and waiting to add more people to my colony, In my opinion I think more crops with a dedicated cold crop would be better to break up the monotony of just spamming beets/wheat/berries, as for tech I would like to see some kind of teraforming tech to turn certain parts to dirt and certain parts to farmland as a late game tech. 

TL;DR 6.5/10 for me, though i dont love samey city builders so it may change for you, certainly try it if its on sale

142356460.review: There's a bit of a learning curve but this is a really fun, creative and dynamic city builder. Wandering around the world makes the game play really interesting, you end up in different climates which effect your farming, you can send out teams to explore different sites. It was difficult on the first play through to know what to focus on. Most of my village didn't survive because I was too focused on collecting resources. You really have to adapt to the different events in the game. If you're wandering through the desert for example, you need to adjust what type of crop you're farming and consider how much water you can collect. My favorite aspect of the game is just how beautiful it is. The visuals are amazing, a fantastic combination of fantasy and whimsy. I definitely recommend giving it a try!

142205815.review:
I played this several months ago and rage quit because of the balance.  The poison was just too difficult to control.
Fast-forward to yesterday.  I tried again.  Despite claiming they've "rebalanced" things my Onbu ignored my wishes to run through it and fell asleep in poison.  I didn't mine its horns to anger it, its stats were all good, and I hadn't pissed it off in any way.  I had half the village trying to stay ahead of the trees and shrubs that turned into poison but the spread was too fast.  This was in the first 20 minutes of playing on the easiest difficulty.  A new player trying to learn the game would be pissed, I know I was several months ago.

Some people have meta'd this and succeeded...which is great.  On the beginner difficulty I shouldn't have to meta anything.  Yes, you can toggle "onbu/villagers can't die".  That's god mode and I'm not interested in that.  I want sliders like, "poison spreads 25-50-75% slower, villagers get hungry 25-50-75% slower, etc.   Dead in Vinland and Riftbreaker are fine examples of games with custom difficulty sliders.  I want the threat of failure but I want to fine-tune the difficulty to my liking.

It's a good game, but I've now been frustrated to the point where I hard quit, twice.  With many other games in my library, I'm content to find one of them to fill this village builder itch instead.

https://youtu.be/nGceSaC4FpI

141661392.developer_response:
Hi Tim

Thanks for the message! During the tutorial, Onbu is only shaking when its Spikes get torn out, otherwise it should not happen (only later in the game during storm events or when you have low trust). See the description text for the Onbu Spikes in the game.

When you need stones in early game, I recommend you harvest the freely available stones on the ground. There should be enough laying around. The Onbu spikes should only get torn out, when you're really in desperate need of stones or you need the place to build a building there. But at the cost of losing Onbu's trust and a shake, which can destroy some buildings.

We're thinking about some solutions to explain this mechanic better, so thank you for your message and your patience.

Please let me know if the tutorial plays properly when you're not harvesting Onbu's spikes.

Thank you and cheers,
Markus

141576633.review:
I love city building, colony management, and automation games.  This one had a really neat take on it, that I was excited to try.  I think it missed the mark, though.  The tech tree is very shallow, with the only real barrier being RNG locked behind finding shrines.  I found the constant need to toggle between the world map and the city map to dispatch my scavenging parties to be disruptive and tedious.  Maybe I missed an auto-collect all setting on them or something.

I got 5 hours out of it.  The first two were pretty cool as I explored the concept of the game, and enjoyed the artwork that's well above average for this genre of game.  The next three were me wondering if the game was going to open up into something more than the small handful of events.

Maybe this game would be a good fit for some folks who like the genre, but it fell short of what I wanted from it, and I gotta give it a pass recommendation.

141181664.review:
This is a cute game, and I like the premise a lot! 

Things I really like:
- Onbu :)  
- Worldbuilding/lore - it's great!
- Looking after your villagers + looking after Onbu + exploring the wider map

I have a few minor gripes:
- the villagers are so so so painfully inefficient, and the worker management is a bit lacking. You can't really prioritize which buildings you want to have employed first, so you end up playing a game of musical chairs when trying to reassign workers from one building to another. Add on that your workers spend a lot of time dicking about, and it's a wonder anything gets done! I regularly feel like my villagers take the least efficient route to do anything. Your workers also just require a lot of micromanagement - you have to manually tell them to heal + feed Onbu, you have to remember to switch all your crops to different crops whenever you switch biomes, switch kitchen recipes, and so on and so on. 
- damaged/destroyed buildings from thunderstorms take forever to fix (unless you play the musical chairs game to move all your workers to worker huts and have them focus on building). 
- i wish there were more quality-of-life improvement upgrades for Onbu :( You can feed Onbu, pet Onbu, heal Onbu, etc. but I wish there were more things my villagers could do to improve Onbu's happiness so that when you build things like the bile extractor (which hurt and upset Onbu) you feel like you're making up for it somehow.
- Maybe I just haven't played enough, but I think it would be neat if the game introduced other Onbu-villages that you could stop and trade with (seriously, I have so much wood please let me trade it for something else i am begging you)

Despite the above, I do enjoy the game and I look forward to seeing how it develops and improves :)

141102892.review:
I love this game! The challenges you can face are fair, and the Onbu is adorable. The game can be a relaxing play, but it does have some achievement features that can make you work hard, too. It's mostly making a small town within a limited space while attempting to befriend and gain the trust of the Onbu you are living atop. If you can show the Onbu that you are in a symbiotic relationship and not a parasitic one, then you are able to guide the Onbu to safer roads and it (apparently) randomly walks down carved out paths. If you choose to live as a parasite.... I can't help you there because I never wanted to be a jerk to the creature.

I agree that there are still some things that could be optimized (like a more obvious note that your farm is out of space to plant, not making the Onbu choose go to sleep mere meters from a safe bed, etc.) but it feels like a complete game already, honestly.

My hope is that they include more customization of the Onbu itself in later updates--something I could have sworn I'd seen in their initial pitch of the game, but maybe I imagined it?--or at least be able to name the creature. I just love the idea of a village caring for such a large beast, and I love the idea of personalizing the Onbu even more.

140995642.review:
as much as i want to like this game i just cant recommend it in its current state. its difficult to put into words but it feels like the balancing is just wrong. villagers move too slowly and aimlessly to deal with urgent tasks. for example, even on beginner difficulty it can take my village of 60 people days upon days to clear out spores from the second spore cloud in that save. the only way to get enough manpower to reconstruct buildings after a natural disaster is to shut down everything else including farming and cooking because if not villagers just wander around completely directionless and eat food instead of building.

for lack of a better description it also feels like villagers don't do as much work as they require. in other words, for every villager you take on, the amount of work needed to maintain equilibrium in your village goes up by slightly more than that villager can handle. the result of this is that the more villagers i acquire, the fewer villagers i have free for construction and the longer it takes me to get things built, maintained, and repaired, when it should be the opposite.

i have a few suggestions that i think would make the game much more friendly for new players, quality of life stuff that wouldn't affect balancing in any way as i am certainly not qualified to talk about something that nuanced. 
first: add an option to control individual villagers. too many times i've seen a villager finish chopping down a tree, decide her work is done, and book it a mile back to base camp to have her lunch, leaving someone else to pick up the wood that SHE CUT and carry it literally 10 feet to the construction site, only for them in turn to leave and make someone else actually construct the thing. if i could tell a villager to pick up their own wood and construct their own tent it would make repair jobs much easier, faster, and less stressful than waiting for the goons at the worker outpost to get up and do their job.
second: allow automatic harvesting. when the woodcutters run out of material they should go out and harvest their own, and when i have workers set to harvester they should know the woodcutter is out of material and go and harvest it automatically without me having to manually assign what they're cutting. i know this is not a unanimous opinion but i think it would make the gameplay loop much more enjoyable, especially since even when the woodcutter is out of wood and the workers are set to harvester AND i have trees highlighted the workers sometimes won't harvest for no apparent reason. 

lastly, though this is not under the changes section because i don't know how you would change it, i think the onbu is simply too large. workers need to shuttle back and forth from the head to the center to the tail constantly and i personally think it's silly to require two or even three individual villages on the back of one onbu just to staff the required infrastructure. i shouldn't need to assign half my population to dung duty and place a second woodcutter, stonecutter, berry farm, kitchen, farm, and pantry there just to supply the dung collector and compost heap.

i think this game is excellent. the first forty days of the novice save file are genuinely enjoyable, i love the music, and the concept is all there, the balance just needs work to make it really shine.
140995642.developer_response:
Hi flamekitt-n

Thanks for your in-depth review! We're very happy to hear that, despite the downsides you mention, you still think the game is excellent.

The points you mention are all aspects of the same underlying system: worker management. This is something every city-builder struggles to get right, and we're no exception to this 🙂
We're also not yet happy with how workers behave in certain situations and have various ideas on how to improve this, from various angles. The next few updates are planned to, among other things, improve on the villager simulation, so improvements there are already in the works.

We're using the Early Access phase to our advantage, to try new things and gather feedback, to make the game as good as we can with the help of the community. All your feedback is very appreciated. When we have a new update with improvements, I'm looking forward to you giving it another try to tell us if we succeeded in improving the aspects you mentioned ❤️

Thanks a lot and cheers,
Markus

139780594.review:
I was enjoying myself initially in a gameplay loop kind of way, but then Onbu decided to disobey me multiple times in a row, directly and indirectly causing many of my village's buildings to collapse (twice) right before wandering into a desert I am not at all prepared for. Abruptly the switch flicked from "this is fairly entertaining" to "this sucks". I imagine as soon as I start the game up again there are going to be a lot of deaths. This is all despite patting and feeding the hell out of this thing; never has a game made me want to throttle the cute mascot before. 

Prior to this, problems were:
- How much food and water does my village actually need? There seems to be no real way to track this and I felt like I was building too blindly
- What "friendship level" is Onbu at and when does it stop being a little shart? Is a cartoon heart filling up too much to ask for?
- Took till near the end of the (fairly short) progression tree to unlock the way to generate more wood and stone despite the high need for both of these things, particularly when Onbu keeps farting or walking into tornadoes causing houses to fall over.

Some issues could be mitigated on a second playthrough with the benefit of experience, but altogether the randomness of Onbu just seems too irritating when I had been looking for a more chill village-building game featuring a big cute creature. Maybe if there were a casual mode or better tracking I'll be interested in playing additional campaigns. Best wishes for future updates.

139753706.review: Even on the easiest difficulty the game feels impossible to succeed in. It's a neat concept but very frustrating. In my most recent run Onbu starved to death IN a patch of mushrooms after ignoring my instructions on pathing because it didn't trust me. I get that managing resources and your relationship with Onbu is part of the challenge, but it's just a slow drawn out failure due to something you're trying desperately to care for ignoring you that is especially frustrating.

Pros: I love me a good city sim, and this game brings a unique factor to the table. I love Onbu; Onbu must be protected at all cost! I enjoy the style and mix of 2D to 3D, and there is enough build complexity and space management to keep me entertained. Adapting to the different environments while managing your people is enjoyable for me. I love the challenge of unforgiving wilderness in survival games, so playing on the harder difficulty is a must. Seeing the development of the game through updates and dev broadcasts says great things about the future for an early access title.

Cons: Personally, I wish there was a more customization in several categories. For example, an advanced menu within each difficulty setting that allows the player to adjust the frequency of certain biomes or natural disasters. Secondly, the world is beautiful, the style is unique, but I want more lore to chew on! Maybe I haven't advanced as much in the game, but a story directed mode with a specific plot could be amazing! Every question does not need to be answered, but I would love love love to have more points of intrigue. For instance, needing research and exploration to find out how Onbu's come into existence, or why they exist in the first place. Why is the world ruined? Is there a way to help it, or are we bound to merely survive until there's nothing left?

TLDR; 
I love this game. Onbu is a treasure. I want more!

139432851.review:
Dove head first into this game and I do not regret a single second of it. 

I absolutely adore the clear inspiration this team drew from the fantastic Ghibli movie 'Nausicaa of the valley of the wind', one of my all time favourites as a child. The premise, the danger in the form of toxic spores to even the outfits of the villagers speak of a love for the movie that really resonated with me. 

I'm not quite brave enough to want to try it on higher difficulty so I can't speak to it as a strategy game, but as someone who played it through a few times on novice, I really enjoyed the gameplay. The interactions with Onbu in particular were very much a highlight! I enjoyed earning its trust and being able to feed and cure it of illness, or lead it through areas as harmless to us as possible. The addition of options for the scavengers was a very nice touch. I also appreciate the addition of technologies that will hurt Onbu, as my refusal to use it (probably not a luxury I could afford on a higher level difficulty) gave me a sense of control and leadership over the moral direction of the village. In that sense it was incredibly immersive for me. 

Once again, I cannot speak to its merits as a challenging or nuanced strategy game as I never tried it on higher difficulties, but if you're looking for a somewhat chill time diving into a post-apocalyptic world, trying to survive and build a nice little civilisation then I would definitely recommend this game!

138278642.review:
[b][i]Review updated![/i][/b]

[b][u]TL;DR Pros[/u][/b]
+ Cute & cozy
+ Amazing premise and potential
+ Progress that makes sense
+ Aesthetics and sountrack

[b][u]TL;DR Cons:[/u][/b]
- Repetitive core gameplay loop
- A lot of downtime

The long bit: 

I love Onbu. I didn't have the heart to cause Onbu any pain, and spent the vast majority of my game time trying to keep Onbu healthy and comfortable. Seeing the message that Onbu's tail is wagging melted my cold, dead heart. Sprinting through toxic environments, making sure Onbu is fed so that there is no attempts at eating suspiciously mushroom shaped rocks, and sleeping in the soft fluffy bits. All for Onbu. You can't give me a six legged rocklizardpuppy and expect me to hurt it, I will love it until I die.

The concept of this game is incredible, and I love the potential of it. The ability to move to new environments is something that many games have attempted, usually through resettlement, and have generally failed or caused gripes in playerbases due to having to rebuild from the ground up again. The visuals and soundtrack help establish the setting and biomes, and the mixture of 3D and 2D sprites is lovely. While the paths that you can choose are linear, it makes sense in the context of Onbu being its own autonomous entity.

The game also progresses in ways that are logical. There isn't a lot of nonsensical additions, and essentially everything is focused on survival. Perhaps some entertainment buildings in the future to help boost productivity, even though it isn't too difficult to keep maxed at the moment. The decorations was a nice addition, especially as it is rare in games for them to also carry a practical purpose beyond simply adding aesthetics.

My issue with the content has mostly been remedied! The Ocean update added a lot of new things to do and research, which improved replayability significantly. Additionally the changes in game starting choices is adding challenge where there previously was little. While the gameplay is still repetitive, there is enough intrigue to keep going and try new things. However, game still struggles with the sensation of idleness for me, but that might simply be due to my preference to micromanage to a borderline unhealthy degree.

And I feel like that is still my main problem. Once you learn how the game works, and what each new technology adds, the only thing left for you to do is cycle production whenever the biome changes, and click on the map every few minutes.

But I was correct in my last review! I have changed my mind about whether or not it is worth the price tag. The developers are extremely passionate about the game, and it was part their love for it that made me buy it in the first place. There is constantly new content, and they are active within their own community. I have faith in the developers, and am certain that they will continue to add content. I have essentially doubled my hours since the first review at the time of writing this, which should already be a good sign of improvement! I will keep checking new updates, and look forward to full release.

Keep it up, devs! You have an absolutely fantastic gem in your hands, that just needs a bit of polish ♥
138278642.developer_response:
Hi Cerubine

Thanks a lot for your detailed feedback. We just launched a new Update which should address many of your points, mainly about content, depth and replayability. We're still on the journey and a lot more is to come, but we would love to hear from you if we're moving in the right direction :)

If you have played the update, I would love to hear back from you.

Thank you and cheers,
Markus

138157913.review:
As this is an Early Access review, the first thing I need to make clear is that the Wandering Village I played was fully functional. The worst I can say about its performance is that I could tell when it was auto-saving due to a brief stutter... on 4x speed. It even ran as well on the Steam Deck, despite a handheld not being the best choice for a city builder. 

That's not to say the controller support was lacking. It all worked great and was as intuitive as a genre that was so clearly set up for point-click-hover mouse control could possibly be. 

There was also a complete game's worth of content, with enough variation in the technology trees and environment challenges to keep things all-engrossing until the game said it was over. That isn't to say you weren't perfectly allowed to keep playing the mobile mesa you'd built for five times as long, just that there wasn't enough new to discover or react to for all of that extra time to remain rewarding. 

Everything else about the Wandering Village experience is exactly as advertised, though I never did feel the need to zoom down to my villagers' eye line. The casual, nature-focused art style was supported by a New Age-y, lost-to-time soundtrack that I would have called repetitive if it didn't fit the mood so well. Together, they can almost convince you that the world's not so harsh after all. If you can avoid the temptation to let your guard down, you might survive, even thrive, in a land covered in poisonous plants set against just that.

137299979.review:
While the concept is interesting and the artwork and music are beautiful, the gameplay is hampered by its tediousness and rigidity. Even for a civilisation building game, it drags on for longer than it needs to - making a initially interesting game quickly boring. 
I've tried changing up my play style to see if I could glean more fun out of it, but each time I got bored after about an hour, then started a new game.

The NPC's are slow and overly simple, often leaving them to get stuck or just stand around even when you've given them a seemingly simple order. And the 'complaining' mechanic can go die in a fire. Having your workers start protesting their conditions, then start standing around and refusing to work is counterproductive. I can't upgrade their conditions, if they refuse to work.

Which ultimately lead me to drop the game after only a few days after buying the game. It's an interesting concept. But the gameplay is tedious, and NPC's frustrating and overall makes the game boring.

I can't recommend this game at this time.

137251228.review:
Very fun and with a lot of charm! I love the style and the animations and the gameplay is entertaining. However, after 11 hours, I reached a balanced economy and even though I still had some buildings and other materials yet to develop, I didn't see the need to dive into them.

TL:DR: I love it but needs some improvements to keep my attention for longer.

Things I liked:
- Art, style and animation. So beautiful (just like Ghibli!) and colorful! I would also kill anyone who dares to hurt my Onbu. He's so cute!
- Symbiosis: I love the idea that you can pick if you want to be a parasite to Onbu. Very original and I actually felt BAD losing Onbu's trust.
- The unique gameplay is quite entertaining and has a reasonable learning curve. Changing biomes caught me off guard a couple of times but I got the hang of it and made sure to keep an eye on my crops and processed foods.
- It gets you hooked right off the bat. If you like management games, this will keep you busy for hours on end. Can't really put my finger on it, you just want you village to grow and prosper!

Things I didn't like:
- No replay-ability: Once things stabilized and I didn't need to micromanage as much, things got a bit boring. I knew how to handle change of biomes, poison and events so it became repetitive and I didn't need several late game buildings or materials for my village to be sustainable. I started a new village to be more organized from the beginning but felt more tedious than fun and didn't continue.
- Storage is weird. I had NO clue where all my sand was until I followed a worker to the Scavenger Huts. I assigned so many carriers to move all materials to storage units but I never got them emptied. Also, Food stands didn't work for me. The worker brings 3 or 4 processed foods at a time, they run out immediately so everyone keeps going to the kitchens or pantries anyway.
- Goals or objectives: Someone mentioned how 'survival as the main goal' wasn't enough to make it fun. I might agree. I'm not a fan of sandbox games. Stardew Valley could be considered sandbox but it has LOTS of tiny objectives and goals that kept me coming back to the game even after I finished the main goal. Might work for Wandering Village!

Overall, its a great game with opportunities to improve. I do think management games tend to get stale with time but even though this game is beautiful and fun, it gets monotone after one single playthrough. I hope I get to play this game again after its full release!

135904874.review:
The game is fun, but there's some pretty frustrating aspects to it. At the moment, my review is negative, but I intend to change it when more improvements are made.

1. As other reviewers have said, the lack of an overarching goal beyond "don't die" isn't doing it for me.
2. Villages die *WAY TOO EASILY*. No food for a few in-game hours? Boom, your population is cut in half. These people have the energy reserves of mayflies. In fact, as far as I can tell (not scientific), being poisoned takes longer to kill them than not eating.
3. I don't like that I can't zoom out to see more of the village without going into the "See the Onbu" view. This tripped me up dozens of times when I was trying to apply priorities to harvesting over a wide area.
4. I *hated* having to micro manage harvesting rocks and trees. This is something that should be happening automatically.  Either make harvesters at the workpost auto-harvest, or make builders that need stone go get stone, or make stonecutters who are out of stone go get stone. The villagers aren't stupid, they aren't going to sit on their thumbs and say "Gee, i really need stone, but that rock that i'm looking at hasn't been marked as harvest-able by the village leader, so i guess instead of building the granary that we need to not starve to death, i'll just chill".
5. I very much did not enjoy having to manually set priorities after setting something to be harvested. Make it a single click-and-drag.
6. Double clicking on something (e.g. poison plants, rocks, trees, so on) should auto select all of the things of that type that are visible on the screen.
7. There is no UI indicator on how much the Onbu trusts the village, major information gap, and the player may not even realize the Onbu isn't following commands like which direction to walk in. Took me 4 times before i even realized.
8. My Onbu decided to sleep in the middle of a toxic storm within 5 minutes of starting the game.  Really? That's not OK. The Onbu shouldn't be suicidal. It's one thing for it to refuse to run through something dangerous, it's an entirely different thing to have it literally lay down and take a nap while it's being actively harmed. At worse it should slow down to a crawl, but never sleep.
9. I randomly had my Onbu go from 100 health to 20 health without any kind of UI indication, or explaination. I could not figure out if it was caused by environment damage, or something that I was doing, or what. The game needs to make the health of the Onbu significantly more in-your-face. Any damage at all should cause a noise and UI ping, and lots of damage in a short period of time should force the player to pay attention.
10. My Onbu walked through a thunderstorm, and half of my buildings were destroyed. Unacceptable. Something that took me 20+ minutes of real-world time to put together demolished in under 20 seconds with no warning. I literally shut the game down when this happened because I was forced to go find every building that was destroyed and click "rebuild". Buildings need to be able to survive no less than 3 damaging events before being demolished. Add a repair and/or maintainence mechanic to give the player flexibility on "fix" verses "rebuild". But just demolishing half my buildings, and then requiring several minutes of busy clicking to ask for them to be rebuilt is rage-quit level of bad design.
11. I unlocked huts, an upgrade to tents. I clicked two tents to be demolished to make room for a hut. It took 10 minutes for my villagers to actually demolish the tents, they were apparently off doing who knows what. Demolishing buildings is very short time cost, so it should implicitly be prioritized above other tasks.
12. Allow the player to place buildings over other buildings, with a confirmation box asking if they're sure. I should not have to *first* destroy the existing buildings, wait for the villagers to get around to it, then remember to check back to see if i can place the new building.
13. I absolutely do not like the "Change out your crops when the Onbu moves to a new biome" mechanic. If you're going to keep this mechanic, then allow me to set a schedule that tells the villagers what crop to plant in which biome. The player should *NOT* be needing to micromanage this.
14. Kitchen produces 3 polenta for 3 corn. Am I not understanding something about the food mechanic? as far as I can tell, this provides the exact same amount of "food" per crop, but by adding 1-3 villager's worth of labor to it. Change it to be like the other crops early, 3->5.
15. I don't like that the Herbalist is it's own stand-alone building, when it's literally just a farm with a different name. The healing herbs should be just a different crop to pick from in the list.
16. Same with the mushrooms. The mycologist should be merged into the farm building. 
17. Add dirt crops. One to start the game with, and then another set of researched crops that can be unlocked.
18. I hate the cactus farming mechanic. It's a very labor intensive solution that can be easily worked around by building a crapton of air-wells to tide the village over.
19. Why can't I tap into the Onbu to get water? We can get blood to make blackpudding, but not water?
20. Not being able to rotate buildings is very annoying.
