135209280.review: I was drawn to this game because I'm tired of city builder type games that require the player to serve the capitalist objective of exploiting every possible resource for production until the land is bankrupt. In some ways the colony you build on top of your Onbu is a little more socialist, a little more sustainable than that, but more because of arbitrary conditions set by the game than because of any fundamental change in approach to the means of production. You can harvest berries forever, not because you exercise any restraint in how you harvest them, but because they are programmed to be infinite. Saplings will always continue to grow, but not because you altered your consumption levels of wood or lumber, rather because you simply exploited more mother trees to produce more saplings. It almost looks like an ecological approach, but you're really only ordering the production of more trees for their exploitation. They serve no other purpose, and they are as limitless as the berries. (And why are we planting crops that are horrible for soil retention like corn and wheat and in general adopting unsustainable agricultural practices?)[list][/list][list][/list]You are put into a symbiotic relationship with your Onbu, in the sense that you need to feed it and heal it and it provides you with safe land for your colony in exchange, but this has very little bearing on the overall philosophy or design of your colony. Like an Olympian god, it will smite you if you displease it, but your day to day mining of the land on its back otherwise is a distinct and distant exercise that doesn't involve it in the slightest. It won't even fill your granary on a whim if you hold a festival in its honor. There are two different types of games being played. One is the standard maximal exhausting of all useable resources for the benefits of production. The other is a tamagotchi minigame where you feed your Onbu and keep it happy so it doesn't shake its back. They are barely and only superficially connected, and the only restraint you have to exercise is in not ripping out too many of its rock spikes or sucking too much of its blood without petting it enough to balance out the exploitation.[list][/list][list][/list]Why does your colony have the option of turning the Onbu's blood into a resource? For more ways to interact with the animal and see the trust mechanic in play? It's insane to me that these people (the colonists) would think of harvesting the animal itself, and I find jarring to even have it there as an option.[list][/list][list][/list]The Onbu is introduced as an ancient, legendary creature who has presumably awoken from centuries of slumber due to the enroachment of poison across all the lands. This brings a distinctly white colonial flavor into your interactions with the animal. Without you, the Onbu would not survive in its own habitat. It needs you to find it food and keep it not dead. It can't even survive the heat of the desert, where it has been hibernating for eons, without you to bandage it up. It makes no sense that this wise creature wouldn't be the one showing you how to not get wrecked by the dangers out there, or teaching you a unique form of bending, or watching on as you wither and die pathetically because you didn't have a clue. Your colony (and it is a colony) doesn't die on the back of its own mistakes, it dies when the Onbu it claimed ownership over dies. I get that the animal is not entirely within in its element due to poison and the apparent disruption of ecosystems, but dear lord this thing is helpless without the settlers on its back telling it how to do the things.[list][/list][list][/list]I think there are some deep philosophical flaws in the current approach. It feels incoherent, and I'm still just putting up quarries the same way I would in any other city builder game with natural resources to exploit.

The other reviewers who say the game is a little light on content are correct, as I have played about 4 hours am about a quarter of the way through the tech tree, and can see what every single building in the game will do and how things will progress. But at the same price of a blockbuster movie ticket, a game with eight hours of content isn't bad. I love the art, the gameplay is simple, and coming from games which are a lot more hardcore, both in aesthetic tone and in difficultly, this game was perfect to relax with. That said, I did see some research with torturous-sounding names, like "blood extractor," and "black pudding" so if you are also coming from Stellaris like I am, but wish to continue committing unspeakable acts instead of settling down for something more peaceful, you can continue your reign of terror.

The most striking thing was building the first few buildings, then pressing the "Onbu View" button for the first time. The visual effect of panning out to see the creature your village is built upon and still seeing your village was quite pleasing.

134195040.review:
Fun, but very easy. It's a great game to sit down with for a couple days and build a big sprawling village, and you'll probably get at least 10 or 20 hours out of it, but I don't see myself wanting to come back to it too much.

It's biggest strength is it's visuals - it's still fun to zoom in and watch the villagers going about their day in the Studio Ghibli-esque visuals even at the end of the playthrough.

Sadly, looking at things or fast-forwarding will occupy the vast majority of your time, because this game is very simple and not challenging, even on the hardest difficulty setting. It suffers from the problem that many similar settlement building games suffer from: the first 2 hours of your run will be difficult and you'll feel like your decisions matter, but as soon as your economy is set up, everything starts playing itself and you begin to grow exponentially way faster than the challenge can keep you in check. 

However, if what you're looking for is a relaxed and forgiving romp through a charming village. If you want to place houses and manage resource flows with a little bit of threat to it interesting, this is probably a good pick up. But if you are looking for a more engaging, thoughtful city-builder that will force you to make difficult decisions, play Frostpunk instead.

Absolutely beautiful game, on so many aspects! Makes you keep playing and playing, and keeps you engaged for long time, even in the current state, and the additional features planned by devs as shown on roadmap will surely make it even better!

The visuals are absolutely stunning! The villagers and buildings are a pleasure to look at on the closest zoom!

The music creates soothing atmosphere, which ideally fits this chill city builder! Each biome has a different theme, which is equally pleasant to listen to, and they don't get boring even after several hours of gameplay.

Attention to detail is amazing. For example, houses of the same type have few different visual variants, so there's a chance they won't look exactly the same when placed next to each other!

Great Worker Management UI - simple and quick to use to add/remove workers in specific type of buildings!

Steam Achievements encourage to start new runs and try different builds, where you don't build certain buildings and try to survive for 100 days - kept me engaged and they weren't too hard, which is good, still got some to earn.

Absolutely worth it, such a wholesome game!

9/10

132237744.review:
It's definitely a nice city-building game. Though there's two things I would ask of the Dev's to improve the game experience for me. But other than those two things, I can definitely see this game taking a LOT of my time and being very enjoyable for me. Highly recommend!

Devs. I suggest the following. Of course, it's ultimately up to you, but I know that at least my experience would be enhanced with the following changes.

1. Add an Onbu Trust Meter.
Being able to see how much trust I'm gaining or losing from certain actions would definitely help in the planning and the cost-benefit analysis of said actions. For an example, does giving a command reduce his trust? If so, I'll only give commands when it's necessary and let him do his own thing otherwise. Does feeding him before he's at 20% hunger give me less trust than if I waited until he was more than 20% hungry? How much trust is lost by extracting Bile or removing a spike? That sort of thing is what would be nice to know or at least see with a trust meter.

2. Now this one I'm not sure if it was a bug or what, but I suggest having all hazards damage Onbu in some way, and that if Onbu is within a hazard area that he will refuse to sleep until outside the hazard area.
I'm suggesting this one primarily because in my first play through, Onbu chose to fall asleep inside a medium storm hazard area after refusing to fall asleep before the hazard area when I tried to get him to. Plus, he refused to wake up or move until his tiredness was below 50% meaning that the storm passed over Onbu and the village 3x. This destroyed nearly everything I had built and there was nothing I could do about it since I was trying to do a nice playthrough where I never hurt Onbu or intentionally lose his trust. Mind, this was on the tutorial difficulty too. So I'm not sure if that was an intentional mechanic where Onbu takes revenge for causing his trust to go below a certain point, or if it was a bug of some kind, but it definitely detracted from my experience and caused me to stop having fun since it essentially forced me to rebuild everything.

Now other than those two things, I think you've got an amazing creation on your hands devs, and I can't wait to see how it keeps improving from here!

I think this game needs to develop some more complex resources and events. The lack of building complexity makes building a complex city unrewarding. The lack of events that feel impactful makes the game feel monotonous. The lack of some kind of (even nominal) endgame objectives makes the game feel aimless. 

I will be watching for more updates and I hope this game realises its potential!

132168110.review:
Addictive resource management game-there's lots of ways to succeed and fail, so you can balance the correct difficulty for you. The art style is lovely and the soundtrack is well done; for early access I've come across surprisingly few bugs. If you like this style of endless sandbox survival games, this is a good one. 

Accessibility wise the hotkeys are re-bindable, and there's no flashing lights, though I would like to see the option to turn off screen shake for when storms pass over you. There is no colourblind mode - the devs should check that poisoned plants and the like are visible to people with various vision needs. The bottom left has a log of what is happening, so it is easier to track which is helpful as no dialogue really occurs, so it functions as subtitles for the game. You can change the speed of actions as well, which allows for more time processing and decision making.

I do feel you should be punished more harshly for harming Onbu (ie when taking bile, harvesting, etc), but maybe adding a way to adjust spawn rates of things like trees, berries, rocks, etc might be a good way to balance those changes. I wish there were more interaction buildings so that you could play with Onbu, and hopefully more on the entertainment side of things as well (your villager's happiness could be improved by an arcade for example, or knowledge increased by building a library which would take a lot of knowledge to build in the first place, etc). There's lots of room for growth with this game and I hope the devs continue to work on it!

A great game with an intriguing concept and engaging management.

132149745.review:
I very much enjoy this game. I always play on the hardest difficulty, and I can confirm on the hardest difficulty it does pose a challenge, my poor Onbu did die once. Of starvation, since I walked through too much desert. It was quite sad. 

I also had the misfortune of running into way too much poison too early on in one playthrough, so had to abandon when land turned into a poison plant nightmare. 

Once I got the hang of things it really improved, especially with some of the end-game technology which makes the game much, much, much easier to survive. One hint I will provide is that decontaminators are extremely useful, so villagers don't have to harvest toxic plants themselves and get poisoned. Bile collection is super helpful (and doesn't require a villager, a major, major plus), though it does hurt Onbu a little, thankfully you can turn it off so only need to collect bile on as needed basis. Blood collection also similar benefit, for an endless source of food though it hurts Onbu so have to make sure there is enough herb production to heal. Having two scavenger huts once town has a bit more population was extremely helpful, there is always something for them to do and they are wildly productive when it comes to resources like wood, stone etc. Also the best way to get new villagers, most I've gotten so far is 5 from settlements, which is a game-changing boost, especially early on. Also love that there are side events / stories from scavenging, really liven up the game :) 

Herbs are a must, to heal your villagers and Onbu, too much poison creates a cascade & at a certain point it becomes insane to try to overcome it. Kitchens are very, very important for food efficiency. Once Onbu trusts you it becomes much easier to survive, can order it do all sorts of things like lie down so you don't have to walk through a poison cloud, tornado, sandstorm or thunderstorm, run to get through poison jungles and other nasty path conditions...also sleep in ideal places and more. Dung collection is so helpful for compost, or alternatively biogas (saves having to injure Onbu for bile). 

I appreciate how every advancement in tech improves survivability - E.G. the different crops are adapted to different biomes, and it is critical to pay attention to the poison levels, humidity, temperature etc. Nothing felt arbitrary. I especially appreciated the progression from tents to huts and cottages, huts are game changing. 

I very much look forward to seeing what the world map looks like with a scout tower once I finally get there, and also to future content, this game has a lot of room to grow, for an early access game I would call this a fantastic start! Many hours of enjoyment, well worth the cost to me, looking forward to many more.

131863833.review:
This is a really nice game, or rather: It looks as if it is shaping up to be one. The idea is quite nice, and so is the artwork. Will definitely keep this game and wait to see what will be added in the long run, as others have said that there isn't quite as much content there. 

The start is quite easy and a tutorial guides you through it with quick tasks/quests. Soon, you will have your little town running and you get to pick what to research next. 

However, one thing that bothers me so far is the balancing (others have pointed this out as well): Once your Onbu walks through poisonous mushrooms, things will become stressful. Your villagers get poisoned, and that poison will keep spreading. If you haven't researched the incinerator yet (which will have your villagers burn poisoned plants), you may have a hard time. 

It was quite funny: I played the tutorial on my first playthrough, my Onbu walked through poison, I had poisoned plants and villagers and then all my buildings started to collapse. Since you have to tell your guys to actually cut trees and gather rocks so you have resources to rebuild things, I suddenly felt like I was an overwhelmed juggler of chainsaws. 

And soon, since the huts and kitchen had collapsed and there was poison around, my village died due to starvation and poison. It wasn't fun to see all my tents collapse at about the same time... maybe an asynchronous decay would be better or more "realistic", where the timer is more random, so that not all tents you built at the same time collapse at the same time? 

On my second playthrough, I didn't use the research suggestions, but went for the doctor and incinerator early on. Also, this time, the map was different so it took some time until I had to deal with poison. This time, it worked and I was at the point where I also was able to feed my Onbu and stuff. However... next stop for the Onbu was... a desert. Where I couldnt collect water. Which meant, my farms couldn't produce food. Which meant my citizens were starving. The Onbu then went to a crossroad. Right: Forest and water. Straight ahead: Yet another desert. Guess which way he went? At least he was asleep when my final citizen passed away. 

Lesson learned: Build more water collectors. Maybe research Onbu controls earlier on. So... start over and I am looking forward to playthrough #3.

The first & second playthrough ended quickly (this was on the easiest difficulty), but I am motivated to start over and apply what I have learned. The beautiful design of the whole thing keeps me coming back, and I do hope that eventually, the devs will change the balancing slightly. 

THis looks like a really fun game, the basic idea is really cool, and I hope they'll keep adding things and rebalancing it... the game does deserve some attention, it would be well deserved and I wish the studio all the very best! Will keep this installed and keep checking back to see the upcoming changes.

131626335.review:
I have just a little under an hour played with this game and overall I have enjoyed it.  It is an unique city/base builder that is done in a cute art style.  

The major uniqueness to the game play is that instead of seasons coming and going, your creature (Onbu) walks through different regions that have different biomes, thus subjecting your villagers to different weather.   Along the way a blight will occasionally infect your trees, bushes, villagers and so on.   This blight if it hits you early on can spread quicker that you can contain it if you aren't prepared, as I clearly was not during my first game.  I still may be able to pull through but it isn't looking good.

Another unique part is that you can somewhat control the Onbu by having it potentially changing it's direction on the world map.  You can zoom out and see various paths, sometimes ahead you might see the possibility for new villagers or possible dangers.   Even though you can try to influence the Onbu, from what I gather it is not a given, just a possibility. 

All in all the game performed great on an aging i5-7400 @3Ghz run 16GB Ram, 1060GTX and Samsung SSD.  I experience no crashes or bugs during my playtime.  That's always a plus even more so with a EA game that released not too long ago.  For the price I do recommend it for fans of the City Building genre.  

It is Steam Deck verified, I haven't tried it yet on the SD, but I will do so and report back on how it runs on said platform.  That being said, I am not a fan of running RTS type games on the deck and prefer good old mouse and keyboard.  That said it is nice to see it is a SD Verified game.

131293684.review:
[I]A key was provided by the developer for my honest feedback. All opinions herein are my own. [/I]

The Wandering Village is a city building game that is set rather uniquely on the back of a giant, nomadic beasts. Its name is Onbu, by the way. Most of the challenge comes from managing resources when changes in biome force you to change up what is planted and how much water is available, but there are also poisonous clouds that, well, poison your nomads as well as cause poisonous plants to grow on Onbu's back and they'll take over if you don't deal with them quickly enough. This is an early access title, meaning it is subject to change as more updates roll out. 

Typical to the genre, you have access to a small pool of buildings to begin with and then you're able to research more. This includes things like kitchens to cook the crops you grow, stations that refine stone and lumber, structures that allow you to interact with Onbu, and so on and so forth.

Because Onbu is a living, breathing organism, your village is subject to different seasons and conditions based on where he roams. At first, you have limited control over this and are left at the hands of the RNG, but as you unlock more technology and gain Onbu’s trust, you can

Different biomes have different dangers and also weather that affects what can be grown. The rainforest biome, for example, is humid so you can collect water via passive structures, but it also has the highest amount of poison, which places both your villagers and Onbu in danger. The desert has no water, which means you'll need to actively grow cactuses in order to sustain other crops. It also has very little poison, but there are environmental hazards to traverse so there's definitely a trade-off there.

[H1]Steam Deck compatibility[/h1]

It's marked as playable, but this game works extremely well on Steam Deck. Right joystick acts as mouse with the R2 trigger as a click and the D-pad can be used to pause, slow, and speed up gameplay, and the left trackpad brings up a radial menu for regularly used shortcuts like the building menu. This is all without any need to fiddle with any settings! 

A controller configuration was actually added in a patch while I was getting this review together and it works flawlessly. If you still want to play in mouse and keyboard mode, the above still applies.

The text is completely readable.

[H1]Things I really liked[/h1]

[List]
[*]Onbu. I didn't expect to, but I grew very attached to the critter during my playthrough. I made the mistake of harvesting from these weird-looking spires of stone to support the growth of my budding village and the moment the message popped up that Onbu didn't like me doing that, I stopped. Never harvested another. Now my expedition team has to work twice as hard to gather stone, but I am fine with this.

[*]The difficulty isn't particularly high at the lowest difficulty (Novice), but then I'm not playing to struggle. I just wanted a chill experience in which I could build a city on the back of a giant and I got just that. I'm sure at higher difficulties the game can be pretty intense.

[*]The give and take of keeping Onbu happy and healthy versus benefiting from its suffering makes you strategize. Seriously, you can harvest blood and bile from Onbu (!) for the greater good of protecting your village from poison and whatnot. But at what cost?!

[*]The aesthetic. The whole game is so pretty: from the lush fields Onbu likes to nap in to the villagers rushing about in their day-to-day when you zoom all the way in, The Wandering Village is just nice to look at. Seriously, check it out:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2921550709
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2921550835

The music was also a soothing accompaniment.
[/List]


[H1]Things I did not like [/h1]

[List]
[*]The inability to relocate structures. Now, I don't mean homes and more complicated buildings; it would be nice if I could move that badly placed storage bin that I didn't think out properly in the early stages of my playthrough rather than have to find the manpower to destroy and then rebuild it.

[*]Poison plants and their spread. Gross. It was difficult to contain even when setting them to highest priority because my nomads wouldn't get to the furthest reaches of Onbu in time. I'm not saying remove them or anything, as I understand that's a big part of the challenge, I'm just saying I didn't like them.
[/List]

[H1]Some things I'd like to see in future updates:[/h1]

[List]
[*]More interactions with Onbu. What if your nomads celebrated Onbu on occasion with festivals, etc for being the biggest, good boi? Decorated his back and threw a big old party that granted some sort of buff to your village's productivity.

[*]More variety in types of food you can grow and more types of cuisine you can make. There's only a handful of dishes you can make in the kitchen currently (four, not counting bread).

[*]More biomes. The roadmap lists two already: Ruins and Water. Great. I look forward to seeing those fleshed out!

[*]More ways to get food. Fishing, hunting, raising livestock. I'm not sure how difficult it would be to implement these things, but even if fishing/hunting were just random events that Onbu came across in its travels, that would be awesome. Or maybe you could come across fishing holes in the new water biome. 

[*]More random events. I saw the same handful of events—recruit nomads, power on ancient saws, trade with slavers—again and again. Some more variety would be nice. Suggestions: festivals/celebrations, crossing paths with other Onbu/giant creatures, learning tech from/trading with other nomad groups

[*]A more personal relationship with your nomads. Maybe the ability to name them? Have them get into relationships and petty squabbles. Nothing that would require another layer of management or anything complicated, just something to give them greater dimension.

[*]Better ways to protect against poison. Can we have some manufacturing buildings—a tailor, for instance—that allows you to build face masks or something for your nomads? Poison was one of the biggest challenges I faced during my playthrough and it was more of a annoyance than anything. If my luck was bad enough, Onbu would plow through several poison clouds in a row and I'd spend days trying to get everyone back to good health.

[*]Different game modes. Basically just sandbox. I'd like to build without the threat of poison spores and lightening storms toppling my buildings, please.
[/List]

All in all, another great entry by this development team. I'm excited for future updates and will add to this review with any pressing information.

Thanks for reading~

131127657.review:
This game has become my goto  when I have down time. 131 hours invested and thought I should write a review.  Bottom Line is that I am equally as frustrated as I am happy with the game. 

Upsides:
Graphics: a style of its own that is well done and pleasing in all views. 

Music: relaxing and calm with most biomes I've noticed have a different track. 

GamePlay: Its adorable to build a village on the back of a dino. Who would not love that? You employ villagers to specific tasks which can be anything from farming to feeding Ombu to decontaminating your village of infestations. Most of the game is self explanatory and it's all trial and error depending on what the back of Ombu gives you as resources as well as how many spikes Ombu has on his back. Look for where the Berries spawn so you can start close to food. I've done multiple runs and find that planning my village in my head to make the resources I need the closest works best.  

Menu system: this is where the game is easy to play for me.  Ombu has his own set of tools and menu. The basic building and prioritising has its own menu, which they have added to just today. Then you have an overall view on the top for the actual villager stats, Biom stats, and Ombus health bars.  Again, just nicely laid out.  

Replayability : High since each loadout is different, maps are random, including some needed items like sand and Knowledge. Game currently has 3 endings. This is nice because it requires an entire new run with a different focus.  

Downside:  
Weather/Biomes.  Weather events are ALWAYS a negative. I have been hit by the same storm 3 times. There is no weather that helps or is a boost. Your map view makes it very hard to make a directional choice when you only see a tiny bit of biomes to start with. You can expand this further into the game, but it's something that is endgame and I have yet to need to complete it. 

Worker Post: Game needs clearer info on what each job does in the worker post. This took me a few runs to nail down and I feel explaining Carriers move things between spots which is so important. You want a building built? Those carriers move the lumber. Harvesters are your wood and stone guys but can be told to harvest farms you have selected to harvest. Builders, easy.. but General Workers ?? They seem to build roads and hang around. Again I wish there was a clearer breakdown of what each job does. 

Farms: difficult to manage, I found its best to have them plant only, then use the harvesters that get the boost and manually select the items to harvest. Keep water close to the farm as well as a tank, and use those carriers to transfer overfill over. 

Storage system: this was updated to give us larger food storage which is wonderful.

Building: Now maybe this is because I am so far in, but It would be great if the game gave more than a flag on what you are waiting on to finish buildings, especially since it just has the same logo on each. I'd appreciate a view into what is needed for each other than clicking on each individually. 

Idol workers:  There should be an alternative task assignment where I can tell Ombus peeps to carry items from my scavenger posts or harvest berries when not actively working for Ombu. When The dung collector has no dung, then let him collect berries or carry water from collectors to tanks. Secondary jobs that allow them to be of use without me needing to lock and unlock each job one by one. 

Weather events: you get it piled on time after time and that gets just beyond frustrating. There are times I just stop repairing and let them stay down until I am out of the path of whatever it is. A single storm should not hit you 3 times before Ombu gets out of the path. There is no forgiveness. The game shows a block of red danger, yet if Ombus tail is still partially in or close, you get hit. And it's constant events after a certain point in the game. At one point I had stopped playing a run when I realised I was never going to get out from under the spores with 3 decontaminators and Doctors fully staffed. The environment never lets up. Spores, Desert, Coldspells, Heat Waves. Its just one thing after another. 

End Game: Not knowing that getting the statue is the end of the game no matter how quick your run is going (under 2 days of gameplay, about 12 hours). This should be clearer. 

Again, I enjoy this game. I find it relaxing now to play versus in the beginning I was frustrated constantly. I do hope the game continues to expand with more to do than what is currently included.

130807699.review:
G-O-R-G-E-O-U-S!!! This game is in early access and took my breath away. As a fan of colony building games; I HIGHLY recommend The Wandering Village. The Wandering Village allows you to build a community on the back of a beautiful god-like creature named Onbu. Onbu needs to stay healthy in order for your village to reach its greatest potential to survive, where this symbiotic relationship is formed between your villagers and Onbu.

The game is innovative, unique, and simple. The art style is beautiful. The interface is easy to understand and the controls of the game feel great! There are three different game versions for those who are more familiar with colony builders. This game can be random with every new game- so don't underestimate the difficulty in the beginning. You don't have to have a hard core strategy at the start. The game is kind to the player in novice difficulty, when teaching the player the rules of the game. If you are someone who likes the idea of a colony builder but feels overwhelmed by the amount of rules, building, and planning it takes- try this game. If you are someone who struggles with strategy, again, this game might be a great fit for you.

I will not spoil the end game, but even in early access, this game is exceptionally made and still provides an immersive experience (AND YOU WILL FALL IN LOVE WITH ONBU!!!) I cannot wait to see what the developers push for the final game! I hope you all love this game as much as I did when I gave it a try!

PS- there is a discord channel with a great community and even a kickstarter for plushies!

Note for those who LOVE colony builders:

This game has a specific niche and may not tickle the complexity you enjoy in a city-builder. This game doesn't provide the option to simulate the feeling of the villagers, their factions, jobs, tasks, feelings, stories, etc. that Dwarf Fortress excels at. However, even if you enjoy more of a controlling type of city-builder, this game maybe a great escape from something hardcore to something relaxing to play.

130782418.review:
[b] As with any early access game, you should never buy it on promises. [/b] Some devs abandon wonderful concepts and some far exceed your wildest expectations. I'm not going to debate how much games should cost per hour of play, small vs big studio pricing, etc.  

There's no real end, (except that around day 100, [spoiler] you can build a monument. [/spoiler] ) It would be neat if there was some major change in gameplay once [spoiler] the monument was complete. [/spoiler] The difficulty modifiers make for a much more challenging experience and add a lot of replayability. [b] I've enjoyed the challenge on the second and third times around. [/b] I like what the devs have done, so I'm happy to support their development.  

This is a fun city builder that shakes things up with its addition of the onbu that carries your village. It would be nice to see more goal-oriented navigation, so that there's something bigger to look forward to. On the easier difficulties, you hardly have to worry about the onbu, it seems. It's a novel dynamic to either hurt it or not, but I saw no point in doing so. It would be interesting to have more factors at play with it, such as iron being something that is mined from Onbu. To be clear, I'm glad that it's not necessary. I almost feel like it shouldn't even be an option; it just feels too messed up. (Maybe it's a metaphor for us living on the earth and that's the point.) Rocks definitely don't need to respawn - that could help make the resources more scarce. Speaking of resources, trees could also grow much slower. (There's a difficulty modifier for this now.) 

It'd be nice to see dynamic changes to the land, based on biome or that how you utilize the land could affect the onbu's terrain. (That or multiple onbu to choose from, each with different terrain.) It would also be cool if Onbu had multiple altitudes that had slightly different temperatures. (Colder, but windy high zones or warmer but toxic low zones?) Finally, it would be neat if the way you built your village affected Onbu or the world a bit more. (Letting more trees grow made Onbu healthier or the world less toxic, or not enough plants would cause issues, etc.)

My only real complaint is that the music got pretty repetitive. It's good, but I ended up turning it off after a couple hours. It either needs more tracks or less frequency. I think it's a bit too noticeable, if that makes sense. Then again, this makes a great game for listening to podcasts or such.

Overall, it's pretty fun! The art is great and the idea is cool. I hope to see more world-building! (the devs said it's coming.)

[strike] 13 Hour Update: After 13 hours, I'd say that I'm pretty done with it for awhile. There's not a whole lot of incentive to keep playing, since the world seems to just be random forever. [/strike] The difficulty modifier anti-perks make for more replayability. 

21-Hour Update: A main issue I have is that the village never feels self-sufficient. Maybe that's part of the point, so you don't get bored? It would be nice to have workload balance or preset modes, so that when you change biomes or get hit by infection growth, you can automatically, or with one button, switch crops or decontaminators. Additionally, it would be nice if there was a way to get iron and sand without relying SOLELY on scouts. (perhaps deep mining gives iron - a tradeoff, and sandstorms convert tiles to sand temporarily, like infection. This would also make the desert more dangerous as currently, it's my preferred biome due to lack of infection.)

32 hour update: The new difficulty modifiers definitely make it more challenging and engaging. The colder world setting make it so that you really have to stockpile water, herbs, and mushrooms. Not knowing if Onbu was going to doom the whole civilization by disagreeing with my path recommendations was tense. I had to resort to doctors using placebos, causing my villagers to die a lot. I really like the difficulty modifiers. I'm not quite done with my monument on Adept +5 difficulty. I hope that it unlocks something, besides the option for harder settings. (I don't quite understand why the modifiers can be used on Easy/Adept, but they're hard enough on Adept.)

130757202.review:
The game art is very cute and the music is quite calm and relaxing. Love the hand drawn animations for the buildings and villagers, Onbu is a sweety too. Have not encountered any bugs during my playtime.

Here are the reasons why I would not recommend the game currently:

It's not a hard game but if you get really unlucky early on your run might be killed off. If Onbu wanders into the desert for example, because you can't control him because he doesn't trust you yet and you can't grow cacti and you can't send out explorers yet or there is no oasis to collect water from - your people will starve and you really can't do anything about that.
So you will learn to start your village in one specific way every time – which I don't think is fun.

Harvesting poison plants should be high priority always, I do not want to click through 30 individual plants to set the priority high. It's good that their offspring will keep the priority you set tho.

I feel like there's a lot of just watching the game instead of doing something. The game feel overall very slow and I am playing in x4 speed at any time.

A bunch of the research things are basically ways to profit from Onbu by physically harming him. As in taking gallbladder fluid, blood, feeding him things that upset his stomach or drilling into his skin to take stone. 
And it says it will decrease his trust in you and you will have to also constantly heal him so he doesn't literally die because you abused him but overall I didn't feel like I was being punished for harming him. And I think these things SHOULD be punished by the game as you are hurting the thing that protects you, you shouldn't be able to easily get away with hurting Onbu just because you also gave him a snack and a pet. Maybe he should refuse your food and pets while you actively or just recently hurt him? 

Sadly, I am not really having fun while playing, it makes me sleepy in fact.
It might turn into something more fun but right now I do not recommend buying this for 25 Euro. I payed 20 during Steam Sale and I honestly don't think that even that was justified in the games current state.
I played for 7ish hours now and basically “finished” the early access by building the monument and I can't see myself picking it up again in the near future because it's just not very engaging or fun.

130347757.review:
TLDR: A floting ledengary creature like Prachett's Discworld Turtle on  lands following to a natural disaster. A relaxing game for the genre's veterans, helps you to empty your mind while dealing with challenges. With still being under development I believe it will have cool stuff added. As we have access to the developers on dc.  Definitely must play...
You need to make saves, game doesn't autosaves so if you think you messed up,  back to your prev play...

Coffee and Read Version::
When I saw this game review on rockpepershotgun website I found it interesting, it was before the launch I guess. But I noted it down as the symbotic city survival management including a mobile city with an opportunity to send scavengers sounds awesome.(Well I wasn't aware of all the concepts till playing it actually)

This reminding me Terry Prachet's Discworld a legendary life form, gigantic drifting over the lands instead of space. 
UI and gaming experience is fine after 8 hours, I almost lost my %35 to poison due to constructing onbu's doc before the village doctor; the population of 23 villagers were down too 17 which wasreally annoying, had to micromanage and move villagers over buildings to keep it functional. Then I found survivors and 51 strong now. 

I directly dived into the matter,t population is your main artery that's why. So as a veteran of Banished, Frostpunk, or other city sim & survival games since lovely Settlers, Settlers 2, Settlers III & IV (turned back to 2-anniversary edition naturally) Simcity, Fragile Allegiance(must try if you didn't hear it before), Caesar III, and Pharoah I have developed an affinity and certain taste for this genre.

This game has great potential as it's still in Early Access, I have 8 hrs of play mostly on a slow speed to keep an eye on stuff and the map. Due to constructing 3 research huts, I had chance to search essentials when I had the poison or drought or winter hit to my settlement. 

As our lovely Onbu wanders around the land we enter mountain biodome(cold), forest (normal and humid), desert or barren land(hot or arid), and grasslands(spring).
So this affects our farming and crop rotation, each one of them has its own required climate. 
Besides that, we need to be wary of poisonous spores or )gas clouds, typhoons, tornados etc.) - which got 1/3 of my land and I have to extract bile from our Onbu, not good for our mutual communication. It took a quite long time to get rid of that - a good lesson learned there -.

So population is important, but feeding and keeping them healthy as well. You have to keep an eye on your food stocks, and variety(later on in the game as you get population your settlement level increases with new necessities you can find affinity to Anno games as the population cast increases they want more and different supplies)

Left aside the population, if your Onbu eats stones looking like his favorite dish he has constipation for 1,5 days. His belly rumbles too much that several of your building collapse. You not only keep your village healthy, well fed and protected from weather elements you keep an eye on Onbu's health, poison, hunger, and sleep requirement levels. 

So even with core survival requirements and wandering around it's a fun and relaxing experience.  You will find it soothing (unless you are underpopulated and without necessary buildings to handle the crises :) ).

I will suggest anyone who likes the genre to give a try to this gem. Since it's still under development I see good potential for it. 

Stray Fawn Games did a marvelous job  and I am looking forward to send some suggestions on discord.

130283803.review:
Developed by Stray Fawn Studios, The Wandering Village is a colony management simulation game in which the player's village is constructed atop the back of an enormous dinosaur named Onbu, wandering through a vast landscape.
	The game is an adorable indie project, and for me is a wild success in delivering a delightful gaming experience paired with a hopeful and beautiful story of cooperation, struggle, and survival. The Wandering Villages is fun, playable, beautiful, family friendly, challenging, exciting, and succeeds at many, many things. Though at this time, the project is 'in development,' The game is playable, totally solid, and fun. Because it is already great, being actively improved, and has a clear roadmap of additions and updates, the omens are indicating a prosperous career for this title, and the folks at Stray Fawn putting it out.
	One of the stand-out achievements of this game is with the story. Though simple, the story encapsulates a deep and broad set of  histories, beliefs and perspectives. Thematic Elements represented in the narrative of The Wandering Village include Eco-Consciousness, Compassion, Community Interdependence, Intentional relationships, Nature and Weather Cycles, Consequences and Risk-management, Sustainability vs. Depletion, and of course, so much more.
	Playing through this game, I came away feeling inspired, relaxed, and reminded of simple joy. I learned many things along the journey, such as; Beets like to grow in cooler weather, where tomatoes like warmer situations, and; If you hurt an animal, it will lose trust in you, but you can learn to communicate and work together, and; If somebody isn't getting what they need, they will not produce as much and may die, and; If you decide to honor the mystical Mother Tree, she may surprise you more than you were asking for!
	The developers and writers seem to whole-heartedly believe that with some knowledge, wisdom, love, and hard work, we can imagine and create a new culture who respects the Earth, surviving the pollen storm and thriving through it, too. And I believe it with them! The world may look how it is, but When the Powers that Be no longer continue to Be, what will we Be? And, how will our communities thrive among the crumbling remains of an empire passed? What does resilience look like in the time of plastics, frackcking, and mega-storms? We can imagine, design, create, and play anything in life, so let's imagine cooperation, design compassion, create diversity, and play games that help us talk about what matters in life, and how we can best support the Earth and delicious Polenta!@
	Thank you, Stray Fawn Studios!

130238480.review:
The art style, music, and immersion are really great, but the gameplay leaves you wanting. Firstly, there is NO organic pop growth, because people just stop breeding in the apocalypse I guess, so you can get yourself caught in a death spiral with no way to pull yourself out. The only salvation is to luck out and get a crop of healthy nomads to fill any vacancies that are keeping you from getting ahead.

There can be unfortunate strings of events that are fun to navigate and you feel accomplished coming out on top, for example the Onbu can get sleepy in a toxic forest, leaving you basically effed unless you can fight off the toxic plants before they infect your food and starve/poison your people. And because there's no pop growth, if you're stuck there long enough, with no sites to have a chance to find wandering nomads and replenish your population, you just die.

If you do manage to survive, you'll be charged with constructing a "monument" of sorts, a testament to your will to thrive, and that's the ultimate goal of the game at present. Once you do that you can keep wandering, but there's really no point unless you want to get all the techs, which to be honest, are quite gruesome.

I don't know if this product is some sort of social experiment, but this game forces you to commit animal cruelty. For instance, you may run out of stone deposits, but you can harvest a spike from Onbu's back, which harms him and lowers his trust toward you, but you get lots of stone from it. This is the same whether Onbu is awake or asleep (though you should be able to get away with it when he's asleep). Onbu's trust and health become a sort of exploitable resource, which, looking at the development team, is probably diametrically opposed to their political beliefs. On top of that, later technologies involve harvesting blood and bile from the Onbu, which quite frankly, is just gross. You can also harvest poop to make compost and flammable gas to combat the toxin, but that's just poop. The fertilizer doesn't seem to have any effect from what I've noticed either.

Overall, the game is ok, but for its price and current state I could not recommend it.

129726903.review:
I originally couldn't recommend this game because it had absolutely no concept of 'balance'. The game has much improved and it's slightly easier to avoid RNG-based unavoidable death spiral situations; I went from a relatively stable population of 64 entering a starvation mass death event, bottoming out at 6 people (which was just barely sufficient to operate at the absolute minimum with tons of micromanagement) to a current population of 103 with no foreseeable problems.

Someone, it seems, took notice that having a toss of the dice at game start resulting in unavoidable game over conditions an hour or more later was a bad idea.

There are still some oddities at present, mind you; I'm still seeing situations where people perform one task, go eat, do another single task immediately next to the food supply, go eat again, repeat ad nauseam. I followed a Decontaminator walking to a single poison plant and then stopping to eat SEVEN TIMES IN A ROW during my recovery. I still think whether someone is "hungry" is determined with a coin flip instead of some actual meter; it isn't rare to see people starving to death while walking next to kitchens full of food, ignoring eating entirely until they're done, and then entering the eat-pretend to work-eat cycles.

There's also absolutely no task optimization. A decontaminator with full gas tanks will burn one plant and then travel to the opposite side of the map to burn a second instead of dealing with the stuff locally. This means that a lot of buildings are LESS efficient with more workers, which is frankly absurd. Storage, for example: it's possible to put yourself in trouble by building a new storage structure, because people will try to fill them up, which will drain resources from essential tasks. Example:
You're established and have built every tech building. Blood and bile extractors hurt your beast, but they have limited storage and produce things you don't use constantly, so the beast recovers. You build one storage structure, and before you know it, the beast is nearly dead.
Similarly, the new aquafarms. Producing fish requires fish. Producing kelp requires kelp. It's entirely possible (and in fact nearly unavoidable) for production to stop itself; you use the fish in the kitchen and the farm, kitchen cooks all the fish, the farm goes derp. Same thing with kelp.

The game is ALL micromanagement. You want grilled fish? Cross your fingers or keep a close eye on how many fish you have saved up so you can keep making more. If you run out, wait for the next ocean to catch more fish.

It'd also be nice if there was some degree of automation for production buildings, like "grow best suited" for farms, "cook everything" for kitchens, "get fish and kelp" instead of either building two fisheries for each or manually switching between the two, and "produce everything" instead of having THREE labs making medicines. Nope, it's all about having more population of micromanaging everything. People won't even manually rebuild destroyed structures, because someone thought you might want to just dismantle them instead. You might, *but there's already a button for that, why stall auto-rebuild for the unlikeliest need ever?*

In short, there's still some work to be done, but it's FAR better than it was. High hopes for the future. Day 439, 3,185.71km traveled, 'morning appetite' difficulty adjustment. Compared to my original "everyone is immortal but the game started with bad RNG so death spiral for several hours", this is a lot better.

The Wandering Village has already become one of my favorite city-builders and the game isn't even finished yet.

The difficulty level is perfect me. Not so casual that it practically becomes an idle game, but also not difficult to the point where I'm feeling overwhelmed with things that need to be done. Your village being built on the back of a giant creature as it wanders its way through different biomes and hazards adds some periodic chaos to spice up the game-play loop.

I'm excited to see what the devs have planned going forward. I'd like to see things like a few more crop types, more biomes, more ways to gain trust with Onbu, and more detailed Villager and Building lists that allow me to see where everyone is stationed, who is employed but idling, and which buildings are empty at a glance rather than panning around the village. The amount of times my dumb ass has left workers idling in the decontamintors after an outbreak is astonishing.

Overall a great game that's worth its price point, even in its current Early Access state.

129472858.review:
Beautiful, fantastic city builder. One of the best I've ever played, right up there with Frostpunk.

While you manage your people, and desperately try to keep them fed, you also have to make sure the island-turtle thing you're riding on is happy, healthy and well-fed. If the turtle is happy with you, you can steer it and keep both it and your village safe of danger. Or, if you're just stupid, you can try to leech off of it and then act surprised when it doesn't listen to your instructions and falls asleep in the path of a deadly natural disaster.

There's a lot of different systems working together that shouldn't work together, but they do, in a really impressive way. I love the turtle and the villagers and immediately became invested in making sure they both live as long as possible.

The things I don't like about this game is getting the stupid villagers to work. They really have no sense of self-preservation whatsoever, and god-forbid anyone but the specially designated farmers pick ripe produce when everyone is starving to death!

Overall though, it's a great game and you really should try it if you like management games at all!

129222996.review:
So lets start off with discussing what i see to be reoccurring criticism and my experience with it.  

Difficulty:  
Yes when playing on the normal difficulty, it definitely felt easy, as someone who has played games like this quite a bit

Simulation: 
This is far from the simulations provided in Dwarf Fortress and Rim World and you certainly lack the same level of development and control that these provide in that aspect.

Now with those in mind your probably asking yourself "ok so why are you recommending it" and thats because despite those two things its still really fun and really niche.  Your not just managing your villagers and village you also have to keep in mind that the giant rock dragon ur on is important to ur survival.  Maintaining trust by feeding him and healing him so you can help direct him around the world, and avoid storms.  Also the fact your on the back of a giant dinosaur means you have to put way more thought into managing space and resources, since their not quite infinite.  While resources can be gain by scouts going out into the world to gain resources from off dino sights, its never going to be as much as you gain from the back of puff the magic dragon.  Its a super cute, and interesting idea that is embodied brilliantly.  The game is still early access, and i only see it getting better, as of now its definitely a great game that i recommend, with a higher difficulty if you need that.  definitely a solid 20 hours of a few runs and even more if you want to seek those achievments and such.  Im excited to see where this game goes next!

Great game, would definitely recommend.

Edit: 
HOLY SHIT I TAKE BACK WHAT I SAID ABOUT DIFFICULTY
well sorta
but im coming back to update this bc i felt like this recent expierence contradicts what my statements on difficulty say.  Poison dude.  Poison.  Some games have enemies, invading armies, storms, nah, this game its poison, half of my villages population, desolated.  I wasnt properly prepared for the poison clouds, i wasnt paying enough attention to Onbu's route, right through 2 clouds, and my island is covered in infested plants, and in a desperate struggle to build decaminator's, produce more herbs, and cut down as many infested growths as possible while loosing more and more population, making this all harder.  It looks like this may cause the death of what was a 50+ pop village.  Its worth mentioning that in terms of food, ive been breaking mostly even, never having an overwhelming surplus, and this has worsened due to the current poison issue.  I imagine on Veteran these issues are way more difficult and one would encounter them earlier on.  Next play through i think will be on veteran, just to see.  
even better of a game, honestly what an indie gem

128908971.review:
IMPORTANT: The thumbs down is meant to be a "NOT YET, BUT KEEP AN EYE ON IT!".

(I started at Adept, since I played several city builders before.)

After almost 8 hours I got through, but at least on Adept it was way too easy. It took some micromanagement but my people always had enough food, Onbu was always topped off. Noone was sick for long. I never had to gather stone, blood or bile from Onbu. Trees respawn, berry collectors never deplete their bushes, even the small stones respawn. Water collects itself outside the desert. One herb garden is enough to supply all your people and Onbu.

The only real moment of fear was my first infection, but you dont even need the flamethrower guys. You can just unemploy everyone, harvest everything infected and re-employ.

Additionally, exploring the surroundings gives a bit too many resources. Yielding 60 water from one oasis in a few hours does not compare to the time my farmers need to grow that many cacti. Two teams of explorers was enough to never really gather wood or stone from Onbu.

Also researching is pretty bland. It only takes time and Knowledge points your explorers bring home.


Summary: As of now it has a lot of potential. The limited space, having to explore the surroundings for resources. balancing needs of your villagers with those of Onbu. But it does not yet deliver, since the state of the village and Onbu is too stable (too self-sufficient). It needs to enforce more strategic decisions, which in other games is nicely achieved by ambiguity of goods. Make it that some food items are needed for medicine. That iron smelters need wood, that people go on strike when you dont fulfill their needs.
Sadly I cannot recommend it at the moment, but I will play it again at Veteran and wait for what is to come.

Update: I played it on Veteran as well now and I am not sure in which regard it is supposed to be more difficult, as the overall challenge, gameplay and events were all the same ._. I understand that it is Early Access, so I hope that there will be respective updates. All in all the foundation is there and it is beautiful and promising but the devs have to put in a lot of additional work at the right spots to make it really worthwile.

128458537.review:
Get this on sale. It's a great little game, but that's just it, it's a little game. After about 7/8 hours you've done everything. Sure you can keep playing, try a different play style, or try a harder level, but all that's really going to change is the balancing.

I love the different levels of play and management, Onbu is adorable and it is a pretty well balanced game. But I will note that the infected plants are more of a nuisance than a challenge and it is annoying not being able to see important stats like Onbu's trust.

Something that would greatly improve this game is more late game content because 4/5 hours in I was simply completing the skill tree just for the sake of it and I never touched it again after the 5 hour mark. A town management type branch of the skill tree could include a town hall for employee management, an agricultural bureau to manage all three types of farms, an Onbu handling comity, etc. Because later in the game selecting farms/work posts one at a time becomes needlessly tedious.

I hope in the future we see more lore, more living Onbu in the world or another wandering giant option(s) to help make our little settlements feel more personalised.

All in all, a good little game.

128301122.review:
Really good city sim. A genuinely fresh and exciting idea.
1) soothing due to choices of music and attractive visuals. and having a cuddly animal friend at all times
2) Genuinely challenging, needing to address constantly changing climates, manage the needs of your onbu and work around its autonomy and limitations
3) the city building is simple enough not to be initially overwhelming but challenging enough to enable a lot of play time before getting boring
well designed interface makes it easy to manage resources and ensure food production is on track
4) At time of writing, there are no children and new residents must be found in the world. I hated tthis mechanic in every other game I've seen it in, but here it actually works well because you're always on the move anyway
5) the role of luck and trust in controlling your environment adds another dimension
6) needing to send out explorers, take care of your onbu and change crop strategy in different climates means the game never becomes self-managing, but nor is it overly fussy requiring too much manual control of your village

127959650.review:
Your people is escaping some mysterious toxic spores by forming a mutualistic relationship with a stone dinosaur, just like those birdies which feed on parasites on zebras that you watch on NatGeo.  Do expect regular survival elements such as maintaining food and water sources, coping with illness and natural disasters etc. The game is short and sweet. Skilful players can probably complete it in 10 hours. 

The strength of this game is no doubt the graphics and art. The 4 camera perspectives is particularly smart and flawlessly designed. Each perspective associates with a different level of management - map view for deciding your pet dino and villagers' destiny, dino view for managing its basic needs, and village top down view for city building. The village eye level view is fun to watch! Yet I don't see micromanagement options of individual villagers' behaviour or mood. They don't make babies even when I put two of them in one tent.

For the simple gameplay and lack of story, the current price is steep. If you are looking for a city building/ management game with depths and widths, or room for your own creativity, this might not scratch that itch. Otherwise, this is a perfect light bite in the city builder genre . And consider the effort and talent that the artists and designers inject in this game, they well deserve a decent paycheck. Also check out the road map for upcoming contents.  

p.s. I demand point shop items.

127882457.review:
Pastafrola de membrillo:

Ingredientes:

- 100 g mantequilla
- 100 g azúcar
- 1 yema
- 1 huevo
- 200 g harina leudante (harina de repostería con levadura)
- 1 cucharita de esencia de vainilla
- 250 g dulce de membrillo

Preparación:

1- En un bol batimos la mantequilla y el azúcar. Agregamos la yema, el huevo y la vainilla y mezclamos.

2- Vamos incorporando la harina y mezclando con una espátula, sin amasar. Cuando tengamos una masa compacta, tapamos con film y dejamos reposar en la nevera 30 minutos.

3- Para el relleno, mezclamos el membrillo con unos 200 ml de agua y calentamos en el microondas hasta que el membrillo se afloje y quede como una crema espesa.

4- Sacamos la masa de la nevera y cortamos 2/3 de la masa. Extendemos con un rodillo de forma circular y cubrimos nuestro molde con la masa. Pinchamos la base con un tenedor y cortamos el exceso de masa de los bordes.

5- Rellenamos con el membrillo y con el resto de la masa cortamos, la estiramos y cortamos tiras para colocar encima del membrillo formando un enrejado.

6- Llevamos al horno precalentado a 180 °C durante 25 minutos o hasta que esté dorada.

7- Dejamos templar o enfriar la pastafrola de membrillo antes de servir.

There's also good details coming from the developers showing updates and additions coming to the game that I really look forward to. 

There are some elements I would like to see changed. I would love to see a happiness meter for the wanderer so I can get an idea of how it might react at times. Wholesome Frostpunk, that's my two word review of this game, I loved Frostpunk and this game has some similar mechanics in terms of managing a base with insufficient resources while exploring a landscape around it. 126965764.review:
Gameplay first and foremost has set up a very good platform for the game to continue to build up on. It's your classic city builder, collecting resources, building, processing resources for the higher tiered buildings, and deciding the most optimal places for your buildings. The dangers of poison, heat waves, and cold snaps are easily taken care of later on, but when you first start out these things can ruin your run. Especially if you accidentally run into a large poison forest without being prepared, your little village can be wiped out before you know it. 

You can always go up a higher difficulty in order to test your skills at the game, and the availability of moral choices (being able to harm Onbu) can make every game different if you so wish. The developers have many updates in the works, and I personally can't wait to see them.

Beyond the gameplay, the music and art style are absolutely amazing. I like the way the buildings look, and it's especially fun to get all the down to your villagers' level and take screenshots of the village as it spans onward. The music fits this game perfectly. 

As it's in early access, the content is few, and as many have mentioned the price isn't exactly the greatest for an unfinished game. But I'm sure there are great things ahead for The Wandering Village.

Edit, Ocean Update: The game has added upgrades to buildings along with even bigger and better stuff. Decorations! Finally! One of my favorite additions aside from the new ocean biome and all the connected buildings. You can put plants and arches and more Onbu-themed decorations. Due to these additions to the content I'd say the main complaint I had was fully addressed, and this isn't even the end of the updates. A very happy player indeed.

126694682.review:
Such an interesting concept for a city builder game.  It's an interesting nuance having to care for and take from, an entity you're riding.

The game has the usual blend of food/comfort/resource gathering that city building games possess but also adds in a disease mechanic that, caught too early, is really devastating and from which a recovery is difficult.  The creature you ride, Onbotu or something, is not too needy and is pretty hardy.  

One of the interesting mechanics is the ability of the creature to randomly pick a direction that leads you right into a poison field and then may decide to nap while the air is at it's most poisonous; therefore, it behooves you to quickly gain its trust and give it commands.  This process is not nearly as difficult as I was thinking it may be, but I really could not figure out how to gauge its trust other than sometimes it would listen and sometimes it would not.  Not a real complaint...the gamer in me wanted a min/max dial I could watch but I appreciate why it wasn't present.

I did not find the farming very clear.  There's a variety of crops you'll plant, based on the season, and you'll need to research those to have variety for environment and people pleasing, but i found i had to dedicate a farm to one crop, despite having many plots.  The plots were the farms way of dividing up its circle of influence, and my early game was spent trying to share one farm between multiple crops which didn't seem to work -- or maybe it did, it wasn't real clear.  The other thing that maybe wasn't really working right, was a harvest/farm button...which if I'm being honest, I just need the farmers to handle, that's why I hired them.  And in fact, if I selected neither button, they managed it on their own.  Maybe the button was a way to override their behavior but if it was, the buttons seemed to behave backwards to what was happening. if you selected harvest, the Harvest word grayed out and made me feel like that was turning Harvest off...not sure.  Either way, that brings to me another annoying point/recommendation.  I found it best to not only devote a farm to a specific crop, but also kitchens which make the raw food into a refined version.  But there are no recipes of combining ingredients and the kitchens aren't smart enough to just make food out of whatever raw food is available.  So people starved and died, despite options because my kitchen wasn't making any food that i had selected as that raw resource was not available.  So I found it much simpler to have a farm and a kitchen devoted to the ingredient (beets, corn, tomatoes, wheat -- no meat options), which brings us to our next nuance, water.

Water can be skimmed from the air if humidity is high enough and you really need to build a ton of water collectors as your farms will move through water VERY quickly.  The tutorial has you build 2 water silos making you think that's the recommended but I had 10 and still ran out easily with the farming and consumption.   

All-in-all, the alpha is totally playable.  Something did feel missing as I felt I had mastered the game fairly quickly.  The risk of failure was not the real other than bad luck with a poison event.  I even found the scavenging options to be a viable (and necessary) alternative to a lot of my own stone/wood farming and did not find much draw back to having a large colony, although some of my water/farming issues would have been less an issue -- but who wants to let nomads die on road, right?

Scavenging is something i would call necessary and to my knowledge, the only way to get sand for your glass needs as well as knowledge which was fairly unclear at first but ends up being its own currency of sorts you spend on advanced research, collecting it here and there from explorations.  The exploring is fairly basic and text adventure-esque, likely to expand in the future.

I'm going to give it another shot on normal, sans the tutorial and make sure I didn't miss a big part of the game's replayability...which is my only real concern about the game.  will I play it more than once or twice?  I'm not sure it'll get three plays, but we'll see.

126684293.review:
A year or so ago I found this game here and the dev team offered a demo. After playing the demo I followed the game because I planned to get it when it was available. 
Steam notified me that it was available and I bought it. No demo anymore, but since that was pretty janky and needed work it makes sense to not have it there because the early access game will be more polished, right? 
Right?
Nope. This is the exactly same as the demo, crusty, busted, lazy AI and all.
Yep. I paid $25 for the same demo I played for free previously, with the addition of an "end-game" building for the win state, a Wonder if you will that you are rewarded with after you travel to a certain point, which can happen accidentally and for me at around 7 hours into the game. Other than that, it's no different from the demo, not any longer than the demo, and not enough of a game in its current state to warrant the price tag.
The good. 
It's cute, and the concept is interesting and unique. Onbu is pretty cute and the idea of building a symbiotic relationship with your world is right up my alley. 
The bad, 
the AI is garbage and you're literally riding around on the back of the village idiot. 
The UI is slightly less garbage. 
You start the game handicapped by a negative 25% to productivity because the Onbu doesn't come with pre-built homes on its back. Onbu has zero sense of self preservation and will lie down for a long sleep on burning sand, in the middle of a poison forest, or in a thunderstorm/tornado. No matter how much poisoning it takes or how much actual damage it takes it doesn't run unless you manage to earn its trust enough to convince it that it'll burn less of its feet away if it picks up the pace a tad bit.
Sick villagers will stand around waiting for the doctor, a hundred miles away, forcing your medical staff to trek across the entire map, heal one sick villager, then walk all the way back to the doctor's hut. Farmers will stop producing for no reason as will berry huts and despite having a bonus to overall productivity it takes 3 sawmill operators 2 game days to get me 2 planks.
The game is incredibly unbalanced, not just in resource management but in the parasite vs non-parasite aspect of play. One tree gets 3 wood, but it takes 5 wood to make 1 hut to house 2 villagers. Then you get to the woodcutter where 3 logs gets you 2 planks and it takes 5 to build a hut. Stone is the same when it's needed as slabs, it's also a non-renewable resource if you play symbiotic and don't mine your ride for materials, Between the increased cost of buildings and the damage that will always happen from wind or thunderstorms, or when your totally full-up Onbu decides those rocks look just too tasty, you're always scrambling for resources. The line between incident and total fail state comes fast when your workforce loses productivity to the loss of housing or the kitchen and it starts the downward spiral.
It's sad but my attempts all ended with the same feeling. I feel like I got robbed.

The devs don't seem to plan for much in the way of fixes. They have mapped out a balancing fix and an AI fix but the planned introduction of an Onbu punishment building (hope that's some kind of joke) suggests that it won't be much.

125999441.review:
[h3]The Wandering Village[/h3]

has a really nice style for a Strategy-Survival Game and a nice concept with its theme in which Players right away start on the Back of a Giant Creature that, like the Title of the Game already gives away, wanders around.
And with the Change of the Creatures Position there comes also changes to the Environment the Villagers will find themselfs in and the Players has to help them to survive by building and harvesting various different Things.
Also the Creature that carries the Villagers arround require the Players attention from time to time.

The Tutorial is well made and easaly leads Players into this Game and how it works.
With different Houses, Technology, Research and assignable Jobs for Villagers, there is a high variety on how to prepare or fight against challenges that the Changes of the climate, cold, hot, swampy, etc, will throw against the Player.

The best Part of this Game is its nice and, even if its survival, still relaxing and enjoyable theme. If you want to just lean back for a while you can play on normal Speed, or if it isnt fast enough there are sliders to speed up the tempo to force events to happen more early. Even an implemented difficulty Setting helps to get a more preferred Gameworld.
And for sure the best Part are the interactions with the giant Creature. At the Beginning just a low amount, but over the course of a Game the relationship between the Villagers and the Creature lead to more options like letting it know when it can safely rest or to feed it or healing it etc.

For this Game i will not count negatives at the moment, because it is still in an Early Access state.

So far tho i can say, that i am already impressed by it and i am looking forward to future updates in the hope that they implement even more Biomes and Buildings and Gameplay-Options.

I recommend this Game to People who like to enjoy chillig Strategy-Survival Games and who also love simple Graphic, but still artistic style.

---------------------------------
[h3]Points i give this Game (Average: 7,04 / 10):[/h3]
8,7  / 10 graphics (Nice choice to go that 2D Drawing Style in a 3D World, it really gives it a nice artistic touch)
 8,5 / 10 Gameplay (Easy to get into the Game)
6,4 / 10 Story (The Main-Story is good so far, but i would like to see a little more sidequests and unique Side-Character Stories to tell a bite more about the World they life in)
7,4 / 10 City-Management and variety of Buildings (City Management is easy, the Building variety maybe a little bit low, but that is likely to Early Access state and i hope they increase the amount of possible Buildings)
4,2 / 10 Soundtrack (There are a few Tracks, but for the Playtime it takes for one Playthrough i would like to hear a higher variety of Tracks to not getting the same over and over)

I believe i brought this game on sale, annnnnd on sale it was still pretty expensive, but i also noticed (unlike some) that it's an early access game, and while i have currently 'completed' this game, there is replayability if you like to relax to some sandbox building or are a bit ocd like me and like to redo things over a few times to get the best build layout.

GAMEWISE - the game is a bit slow, like honestly there is a speed multiplier but i feel like it needs one more level, and it can get pretty repetitive to farm items, but i find there aren't many games that can do this WITHOUT becoming a bit grindy.
The art/graphics are really pretty, there's basically two kind of art styles and the zoomed out painted style is just so scenic and nice, all the while being kind of catastrophic as you go along and it makes playing the game so sweet.
The story is pretty sad, and i'm sure i'm not the only one imagining the Ohm from Nausicaa as you're travelling through this landscape.

Overall even with the higher price i'm not disappointed in what i've brought or played and I look forward to the changes and full release of this game in the future!

Although this review is negative, it's worth stating the game itself is quite good in many ways; it looks great, it plays well, and it's quite addictive.

I reviewed it negatively to say I don't recommend because it's just not worth the money; after 10 hours I'd literally done everything and if I'm being honest, it had already gotten quite repetitive a few hours before that. £20 is a relatively high price for a 10 hour game compared to some stuff on the market you can get hundreds of hours of fun for less.

125568884.review:
As much as I would like to give it a five star, I'm going to point out a few things that you should consider b4 diving into it.
1. The randomness in respect to world generation forces you to rethink your game play differently each time.
2. The difficulty range and the learning graph are quite unlike other base building games. 
3. Getting in a lot of nomads in your base in the start will force your life becoming hectic. 
4. Crop rotation based on the weather is something i was new to. First run, I managed to get 60% of population killed.

In short, it is a fun filled game and entirely different from what it seems like in the trailer and what not.
I would recommend the game.

Fundamental to game is population, once you have enough people you can swim in resources (assuming you've sufficiently accounted for food. Felt like challenge was focused on surviving longer and longer in poisonous areas without core population dying.

Wandering Village is a superb city builder that stands out from the crowd with its gorgeous paper-style art, survival components, and focus on mutual sustainability as well as expansion.

125153242.review:
At beginning it may be hard to master, but once you know how to plan a village, what to prioritize and how to keep Onbu happy and healthy - it becomes very easy and little repetitive. Story is short for now. You survive until [spoiler]you find one rare discovery, then you have to build one last building...[/spoiler] And it's over. So I hope that full release will offer more story! And more challenge and more variability.

As for being early release, I encountered no bugs. Everything works beautifully.

What's best about it? It's nice to have survival city builder which offers something more than simply building and managing your city. You have to pay attention to the map and keep alive the creature that carries your village. It's a fun take on city builder. Also, Onbu is really cute.
