At this time (October 29, 2022) I would not recommend this game. 

The tech tree is short but takes a long time to explore. The requirements for a scavenger group to get the knowledge for the final tier upgrades also isn't explained. 

The poisonous plants which occur pretty early on don't appear to get out of hand but if you don't drop everything and put everyone to work at them they will never disappear. In my second playthrough I tried to focus more on this but even with a focus on them and every important building related to them I still couldn't even notice a dent.

It is an interesting idea for a game and I hope they fix these problems and flesh out the story and tech tree in the future.

124434653.review:
Very good game, cant wait to see where it goes from early access. Currently, there is no "endgame" but I am hoping the game works towards that.

Big pluses: 
settlers use your paths and incorporate that into pathfinding, which is great for laying out your settlement
there is enough variety and juggling to keep you busy as things go on, juggling crops to plant
game is very easy on the eyes and ears


Con: 
Currently no endgame, but this is early access, so im not too miffed
Research tree is a little too short (again early access, but something to mention for the devs)
sawmill and quarry seem a little underpowered, since you may have to build one for each stump/large rock.



side note: 
Tutorial could be more encompassing. I think maybe the ability to replay tutorial lessons would be cool, since sometimes they just get swallowed up (i thought the only way to use the dung was for biofuels for decontamination, was a little to busy to realize the farm had the compost option, thats also on me so im not holding it against the game)

124011123.review: While i really enjoyed the game for the 5 hours I played, I can't fathom how this is priced at more than $10. After 5 hours in game I had pretty much done and seen everything. The game gets really repetitive, really fast, and there's no replayability to the game unlike other games that have shorter play times. Even when the game is finished and out of early access, I struggle to see how they would charge more than $15-$20 unless they have some major plans in the works, but with the current road map I could see myself getting only another 5 hours out of it maybe. Pros:

-Fresh Concept to city-building basically building on the back of a dinosaur who you must also keep happy, fed, and healthy. You can also guide the creature to specific biomes.
-Can control the speed of the creature to help avoid "disasters" on the map you'll encounter, like speeding up or slowing down to avoid an incoming storm across your path.
-Beautiful to look at. Love the art style.
-Soundtrack is great. Pleasure to listen to.


Cons:

-Not a ton of content. You'll reach the end of all there is to offer approximately 5-6 hours.
-I don't really get the itch for replayability right now. Nothing makes me want to come back and do it again other than really listening to the soundtrack again.
-I really wish you could rotate buildings. I think this is locked because of the art style, but cannot do so. I find myself having to build weird road structures because of this which annoys me.

Overall:

I liked it. It isn't a perfect game, but it is still in EA. Art is beautiful, controlling/interacting with the creature you're building on is a cool concept, music is a joy to listen to. Is it worth the current $24.99? You decide based on what I mentioned above and knowing you'll get through it in about 5-6 hours in one gameplay. I ultimately do not regret my decision and will probably circle back at some point.

123734762.review:
not realy the biggest 
build-sim fan anymore
but this one looked kinda special
and special it is

the base-idea reminds me of Xenoblade Chronicles 2; you basicaly live on the back of a gigantic creature.
at it's core it's a building sim. you build housing, farms, gather ressources, etc. 
the reason this one is engageing stems from the fact that Onbu (the creature you piggy back) is not just a gimmick, but influences every aspect of the game. instead of you having to deal with different seasons, etc. Onbu travels the world and you can see where the journey (might) go, what awaits you and what to look out for. 
there's a given path for Onbu to travel which sometimes meets crossroads; the surrounding areas got gathering spots, shrines, villages and other happening which you can explore via sending a villager party out. different enviroments Onbu journeys through got different temperatures, humidity, and enviromental hazzrads for you to manage.
it's like playing a building-sim mixed with a roguelite game ala Darkest Dungeon. 
Onbu and his needs also interact with you and your village directly (or the other way around). get on his good side and you can "suggest" paths for him to chose; if he can't find stuff to eat or gets sick you can help him out (or it?) and thus gain his trust.
it's all comming together quite brilliantly. the traveling giga creature, you tiny villagers, the need to adhere to their needs, build and expand and explore. 

furthermore this is one of the prettiest games i've seen for quite a while. the 2D art-style is quite unique and animations are stellar. the level of detail in the enviroment and buildings is not just destinct but great to look at. 3D models like Onbu and 2D models like your villagers, colors and effects just blend together. it's a great approach to art-style.
same goes for the music: tribal beats, somber almost arabic sounding melodies just fit perfectly.

easy recommendation, especialy looking at the already low price-tag.

123696229.review:
I love the concept and this game has a ton of potential. The relationship and interaction you have with Onbu really makes it stand out as a city builder/survival game. It's honestly a very refreshing take when it comes to city builders since there are unique challenges that arise depending on how you care for your land and how you choose to interact with Onbu/the general environments. 

 People who are complaining about the price really aren't considering the fact that this game is still early access, and the developers have definitely delivered what they have so far promised. The $25 price point is more than fair considering that 
1. This will eventually likely be a $50+ game after more development. 
2. That money goes to supporting further development. 
3. There is tons of opportunity for the community to contribute to the development and direction of the game. 

The early access so far does not really have a story line or endgame. Its more just experimenting and playing with the basic mechanics/concepts. If this game has sparked you curiosity, I recommend buying it to support the team. There are tons of ways to contribute to the early access development via discord as well.

If you're looking for a finished, polished game, than I would say to wait on this one. However, if you are a city builder/survival fan I highly recommend it. I got about 20hrs in before I felt there is not much more for me to do until we get some more content updates. I am personally very excited to see how this game develops.

123587637.review:
What a wonderful little game, a wholesome new spin on city builders! Though a fairly short game as the game technically "ends" at day 100 but you can continue to play for what i assume is forever. But despite being relatively short, i have no doubt it will be beefed out throughout development and i cannot wait for what the devs have in store! I have played this on all difficulties and I feel like the difficulties need defining and tuning more. Beginner and intermediate feel the same and the hardest difficulty is only hard until you have 30+ villagers and the main essential buildings researched, the late game seems the same on all modes.

Pros:
. Wonderful immersive music that change in each biome.
. Onbu is adorable and its fun looking after his needs and keeping him safe.
. Good AI
. Very stable game, never encountered any bugs or crashes.
. Outstanding use of 3D and 2D assets resulting in an adorable art style.

Cons:
. Early access always has its risks.
. Relatively short game.
. Fairly easy difficulties.
. Some crops wont be used as much as others as some need very specific biomes that I never seemed to be in that often, so villagers always complain about their diet.
. Sometimes the villagers wont build or harvest something until you make it a priority even if there is a low workload.

Suggestions: 
(I understand that some of these might even be in development already)

. Greenhouses so you can grow crops in all biomes.
. Barns/coops and livestock.
. Make difficulties more distinct.
. Villagers age and have kids.
. Schools for kids giving educated villagers boosts.
. The ability to do more with mushrooms (eg. mushroom soup for your villagers)
. Be able to make more foods with a combination of crops (eg. Berry pie: wheat + berrys, tomato & mushroom soup etc)
. More crops (eg. potatoes, onions etc)
. Meet other Onbu and maybe make Onbu caravans were you use balloons for villagers to get from one Onbu to another. 
. Bandit raids on your Onbu + a barracks/garrison building for soldiers to defend Onbu.
. More biomes and more varied random encounters.
. The ability to select a villager and order it to do a specific task.
. Graveyards to honour dead villagers.
. Make gaining Onbu's trust harder and make the consequences of upsetting him greater.

That's all i can think of for now but I'm sure ill think or more things :)

A special thank you to everyone involved with this game! <3

PS: I need an Onbu plushie!

123470857.review:
You're cheating yourself if you play on easy mode.
This game has quite an interesting take on city building, requiring a lot of micro management to deal the environment you're passing through. The game is at its best when Onbu (your kaiju city) either refuses to listen to reason and parks itself in a very inconvenient place, or takes a wrong turn and you're forced to quickly shuffle around your meagre workforce to keep everyone healthy, fed and housed. Onbu will usually listen to you unless you've done something to upset it, but even then there's some fun trying to avoid hazards on a beast that only knows how to go forwards.
Mostly the gameplay revolves around trying to gather/farm food, upgrade your infrastructure and keep Onbu and your villagers healthy. Each biome has a different climate, resources to gather and hazards. Climate is very important in TWV as it determines whether or not you can collect water, which crops you can grow and whether or not the atmosphere will accumulate toxic spores in your village (and Onbu itself). Changing biomes usually involves making tough decisions about who goes where, and which crops you will grow. Tomatoes grow quickly in warmer climates, but are inefficient when cooked, beets won't grow in hot or cold climates but have a better yield when turned into soup. Toxic environments also require you to grow medicinal herbs, which need to be grown and then distributed to both Onbu and your villagers, and can spawn spores on Onbu that need to be controlled with more villagers. These spores multiply very quickly and are a very real threat as they poison your villagers, Onbu and destroy crops and infrastructure.
Losing villagers to poison or hunger is also a problem, because the only way to get more is to find them in the overworld. Running out of food is one thing, but having villagers die whilst moving to a toxic biome with a different climate can really put the pressure on to make every villager you have count.
This makes for a pretty good gameplay loop where you're constantly praying for Onbu to take your advice and planning what you'll do to survive regardless of what happens.

TVW also has a really nice visual style, zooming in on the villagers hard at work (or not) adds a lot of character to the world that I usually find missing in city builders. Onbu is also very charming when he isn't falling asleep in the path of a tornado/spore cloud.
Content feels a little bare bones at the moment but I'm willing to excuse it for early access and because the core gameplay loop is so engaging. If you played Timberborn and enjoyed the drought mechanic you'll probably feel right at home here, although TVW starts easier than the first few droughts it can throw you a lot more curveballs and challenges than Timberborn's drought mechanic ever will on hard.

tl;dr game good, play on normal or above, micro intensive, very engaging

123270371.review:
I definitely recommend it, but there are some tentative parts I'll explain.

The Wandering Village is a pretty unique management game.  You indirectly control your villagers by essentially pointing out the things you want done and then giving that task a priority.  Villagers also work at structures that they build, which takes away from your fluid labor force (general workers).  While you're checking on them, you're also riding a freakin' giant walking animal because your only other choice is a life of poison and death on the ground.  So you also need to keep Onbu--the creature you ride--alive.  You do this by feeding, healing, and curing.  But you can also guide Onbu when you gain it's trust, which is especially important when it comes to the biomes you will come across and what you feel prepared for.  You could also choose to forego the trust and simply take from the beast and deal with what comes.  In short, you have to juggle a lot of important matters, sometimes a few all at once.

Starting out, the tutorial does a good job of explaining what needs to be done, but I feel it could emphasize the trust mechanic with Onbu better.  Specifically explaining the benefits of valuing trust vs. ignoring it.  There is a lot to learn, so it's possible I missed a few details as well, but the nice thing about the game is how it rewards patience and being observant.  You may eventually answer your own question about something just by continuing to play.  I find it challenging to manage, but extremely satisfying and relaxing when things just work out.  But they don't always work out and you can easily cause a lot of problems for yourself if you're not careful.  I managed to avoid dying a couple of times, but even now at 16 hours, I'm in a tight spot again.  The challenge doesn't let up, but I actually appreciate that.

My biggest problems are mostly related to it being in Early Access.  I want more content, more dynamic systems (why even have worker huts, really?), and I'd like a bit more story.  I'm also finding that stone is a difficult resource to keep stocked, particularly in the late game.  There are some random encounters you can experience along the way and I found out that they seem to repeat more often than I'd like.  I'd definitely appreciate more variety there.  And lastly, while I don't hate the price, it is pretty high for what you get.  But, to be fair, if everything on their Early Access roadmap is implemented, it's easily worth that price.

Overall, I have had a fantastic time being awake until 2 am on multiple sessions because there's always more to do and more to improve.  It really sucked me in for a good while.  I highly recommend it if you want a more unique take on managing a small civilization.  

Also, I'd die for my Onbu.

123217528.review:
I am one of the backers for this game during kickstarter.. What interesting to me is the setup which stands out from over saturating market of survival management simulation game.

Story: 5/10
At this moment on early access, aside from intro movie and occasional comments from Village elder, I don't think there is any story exist at all.

Graphics: 7/10
A mixed of both hand-drawn 2D and semi 3D Onbu (the turtle creature) is initially weird but I find myself loving it more and more..

Sound: 5/10
One thing the developers can improve after early access should be the sound. Different music on different Biome is good but overall music makes me super sleepy. Need some kick in sound department..

Gameplay: 10/10
This is where it shines for this game. Initially it looks simple enough. You gather berries, you chop wood, you dig stones. After initial phase, things starting to complicated and I find myself actively managing the village. You build farm but you need to watch out for weather, current Biome and the next coming Biome so that you know what to plant or what to harvest now.. There is no sequential weather. Your weather will change depends on where Onbu is heading. 

You will get several disasters. Most annoying will be poisonous air which not only make your villagers sick, also create spores and your crop will be in trouble. There are tonados, heat wave, and cold snap. I read that the developers are planning new Biomes including water world, which I assume flood will be next.

In the core of the gameplay is Onbu, the big turtle with child like minded. You need to take care of him or else your whole village won't last long even you do everything perfect. He will sleep on poisonous area coz he is sleepy.. He will eat stones that look like mushroom coz he is hungry. He hurts himself walking in the hot sand.

Also, you can either hurt him to survive your village or decide not to do that but will have disadvantage in the long run. Example, you can drill him to get blood out, which you can make blood pudding as food for your village (no kidding!)

All in all, I love this game and I never thought normal simulation can give me so much stress and always on the edge of my seat. Early access is very much refined and I can even consider completed game. With the new updates roadmap, I am excited to see what more the developers can bring to already perfect survival simulation game.

123109444.review:
Onbu is ADORABLE. That's the most important thing. Make him happy, he wags his tail and practically skips forward. Make him angry, he won't listen to a word of advice and will pout. 

The game has two distinct goals: Keep the village alive, and keep the Onbu the village lives on alive. Onbu wanders through different biomes, having an effect on crops and water reserves. The world is plagued by giant poison storms, threatening to destroy all life as Onbu struggles to run through it.  Grow the herbs to keep the poison at bay, and destroy the poisonous plants with fire while doctors rush around dispensing cures. Starvation and poison is always a risk for everyone, so balance the present needs with future expansion and keep that Onbu prancing.

I started playing this game after seeing a demo back in February. My husband and I both joined the beta test list the first day we played, and eventually became testers. Then, when circumstances prevented us from getting the game, we received two copies for free and couldn't be more grateful.

The vibe feels pulled right from Nausicaa and the Valley of the Wind, which also includes poison spores taking over the planet and lowtech humans battling against it. A fun and mostly chill indie title that's already well polished for early access, everything works and runs great. Would certainly recommend to any city sim fans.

122886533.review:
Playing an Early Access version as of September 2022.

A vary slight thumbs-up.  It's a simple village builder, and would be unremarkable, but it features some unusual mechanics you might enjoy.  Interesting for some of its novel ideas.  Almost all the fun of the game is figuring out how the world works and what to do under various circumstances.  Once you've figured these things out, although each replay has (apparently) random elements, I don't think there'll be much replay value in the game, so my thumbs-up is only slight.

Some of the ideas are unusual.  For instance, your villagers never have children.  To increase your population you have to attract them from nearby settlements or just encounter them on the road.  There's no combat.  Well, actually there is: your village can get infected with something and you have to to get rid of it.  You constantly have choices to make about where your creature wanders, and that affects various elements of gameplay.  Figuring out what, why and how, is the fun of the game.

122756698.review:
A solid foundation for an Early Access title but it's a long way from justifying the price.

Of the 10 hours I played roughly 3 or more are just messing around after I already saw everything the game currently has to offer.

There is only endless free roam, no campaign and a limited roster of events. The most difficult part was knowing what type of infrastructure to prioritize to tackle the conditions the game throws at you. But once understood it boils down to flowchart gaming, "A happens, do B" and you often solve problems before they even occur.

The setting isn't sufficiently explored or fleshed out. It's supposed to be a post apocalyptic, dying world. But aside from infections while unprepared, which only really happens once or twice, it's pretty smooth sailing. So the whole concept is confusing. Is it supposed to be a chill city builder with a few outside influences guiding your progress or is it supposed to deliver the challenge of struggling to survive? The whole theme of a symbiotic or parasitic playstyle isn't there either. Parasitic just doesn't pay off. 

There do appear to be a few minor bugs. Like getting notifications about Onbu losing trust because you mined its spikes which you didn't even do. Also balancing issues with certain buildings seeming quite bad. 

Was a good time overall but for 25 bucks and after the game plays its full hand you are left with meager content. Starting a new game makes little sense because it's exactly the same again.

There is more planned on the roadmap. Which is sorely needed. Definitely should have launched much cheaper. I am certain it's going to be an easy recommendation eventually. Just not yet.

I played the demo and beat it in a decent time, it got me very excited for the full version to come out. I love the game! 
a few ideas, whether good or not idk
>the ability to assign tasks to individual people (honestly only matters once you get past a population of around 80-90, even with specific tasks highlighted), 
> a "poisonous plant" specific highlight on the harvest menu, 
> visualize statistics a bit more (specific/expected food IN and food OUT is mostly my goal. or like, expected processed food  - visualizing what I have vs my population needs without opening the villager happiness menu. Housing too, making it more in-your-face or at-a-glance), ESPECIALLY I would love the option to see a list of tasks with their priority in order. For example, say I have a ton of stuff I want harvested/built but then there's building's that need rebuilt or poisonous plants needs dealt with, I would love to be able to see/reassign priority. I get that that may make it too easy because then you're not looking around and individually prioritising things, but yeah. 
>ability to set priority level (level 1, 2, 3) with the priority tool, not just it bumping it up one. Or stacking priority clicks, instead of capping at one. It can get rough prioritizing each individual little poisonous plant. I get around this by having extra people/assigning and unassigning decontaminators as needed, but it is still tedious when you need to do it.
>please for the love of this game give better indication that scouts are back. A popup, a sound, "would you love to send this scouting party on another expedition?" or whatever, it would just make that whole part of the game easier to stay on top of.
>could make "family dynamics" a thing. Specific homes for families, say it gives a popup of "blank and blank have decided to be in a partnership, they will need their own [marital home? idk] to add to the population." I'd make that it's own branch under the research tree, why not. Then you've got useless villagers for a sec while they grow up (draining food stores but not doing work, adds a challenge temporarily - could make it harder and need kids to have a place to go like a Nanny/School Hut or their parents can't work further reducing your workforce until things are remedied) then once they're grown up they can do work. Could make it a requirement to have like 90% happiness level or something before [Marital Homes] and [Nanny/School] are available. Idk I'm spitballing.

 Obviously my suggestions would make the game easier, but with that and the limited space on the Onbu it could make it hard to lose the game. I would love for the size of the Onbu to be upped, doesn't have to be by much, but you know. Or! Some way to expand the size of the Onbu, like a good vs evil way. Evil would be cheap and easy, say cheap knowledge points to forcefully add space, expanding ethically without harming the Onbu could be like related to a new scouting location/trust bar/love bar (could make the relationship with the Onbu more critical and measured and then boom reward of more space, like how you have to build trust for it to listen to you). Or maybe picking up baby Onbu's that eventually grow, so then you have a train of Onbu's to take care of and keep the populations happy on. The more space you need to manage the more challenging the game becomes is the idea.
I did not expect to write a novel here but I do really enjoy the game and I would love love love to see it expanded/adding content. 
You guys did a great job! I played for 12 hours straight when I first sat down to play, and it made me very happy to enjoy a game so thoroughly right off the bat.

122665290.review: This is DEFINITELY a game of PLANNING.  There is no GUARANTEED route to survival and success, but, if you plan poorly, you can very rapidly find yourself falling behind the village's needs and the needs of your travelling home.  I highly recommend going through the tutorial in the order it suggests making things, but, prioritize the creation of storage and the gathering of resources as early as you can (not at the expense of housing, though).  Get trees chopped and gathered, and get stones (the smaller ones and DEFINITELY NOT the spikes) broken up and gathered, too.  Build your Research buildings (I recommend 2, but not more than 3 until later) and set up a series of planned research.  Check over the Research Tree after each piece of research is completed and be prepared to reorder it.  Remember you can SHIFT-CLICK to choose the order and move something to the head of the queue by SHIFT-CLICKing an item twice to move it to the back.  First make sure you add the item you want to prioritize to your list.  Then, SHIFT-CLICK twice on each item already in the queue, to keep everything scheduled in order.  It's marked in the upper right corner of the research item so you can organize/reorganize it fairly easily.  Get a Scavenger Hut fairly early, because those scavenger missions can bring back more people, resources, and Knowledge Points, which are needed for specific Research Items...

122633472.review:
Day 1 Feedback:

Fun little game, after 3 hours I had learned enough to restart my village on a higher difficulty with better decisions so the learning curve isn't too steep. My main feedback to devs so far is to make it so you can zoom out further before it goes to Onbu view to see your whole town.

Day 3(?) Feedback:

Still really highly rate this game. I like that the complexity of the game increases at a manageable level, though if you slack off and don't invest into research eventually you'll be regretting that you can't manage problem X or Y. I've beaten the game now in probably about 12 hours without really trying to min max, built everything that can be built and I think seen every type of situation. I know there is a roadmap for more content but I worry even that is not THAT much more, you really are limited by the size of his back in terms of how you can scale out, and given it's all done now I wonder why I would need to keep playing as well even if I could.

Things I think can be added to improve QOL (particularly at late game):
 - Some sort of unlockable auto for the feeding and healing of Onbu and the scavenging - at the end it really does just become a 'wait for cooldown and click again to make sure Onbu is ok and my scavs aren't slacking off' simulator as the village is on autopilot. It's good to have to do that at the start, but once you've done it... you've done it? Not much fun or value in repeating so many times
 - Ability to see which villagers are assigned to which task at a macro view, like a dashboard for managing them. Again, as an unlockable (maybe a building called Control Tower or something) would work, so you still play that part of the game, but then no longer have to go keep clicking on buildings to see what they're all doing or managing multiple beet farms at once etc
 - I really liked that there is no 'bad guy' persay, but rival villages competing for resources or trying to invade you could make it a bit more exciting once you've done it all
 - If you put something on the absolute highest priority, given there are 4 different levels of prio, that should be cue for villagers to literally stop whatever they're doing, even an assigned role, to do that thing. Someone minding a beet farm off the corner of your map while you're desperately trying to take out the poison shrooms is pretty frustrating, needing to click on every building is also a pain, and there would be fair trade-off because your village would essentially stop functioning for a while

I did recommend this game to a couple people but given it's so short I'm not sure that I'll keep doing that, I know it's an alpha as well so I'm not ignorant to the fact it's an incomplete game, it is just.... very short, even for an alpha. Look at something like Prison Architect as a reference, that alpha was 100s of hours of content in a similar style game, now it's a 1000s of hours game in release.

122613428.review:
I've been waiting to play this game! I'm not one to spoil things by watching dev videos (though I should because it shows support) and prefer to jump in blind with things. After a quick-to-learn tutorial, the rest is easy.

There are going to be moments of mild frustration where you're not sure how to progress - just give it time, expand your village, and enjoy the peace while it lasts. You'll face off against spore storms, thunderstorms, extreme heat, extreme cold, and sudden panic (but fun panic, if that's a thing). 

What I liked about this game:
1.) Minimal list of base resources - there's plenty to be varied and specific, but you won't be drowning in menus of [i]metals, ores, wood, crystals, etc[/i]. 
2.) I also loved the color pallet! There's no clashing colors, nothing is overbearingly bright, it's all very soft and pleasant.
3.) There's always something to do. There's going to be times where it feels like you're not doing anything - that's fine, it will come and go but never be present for too long where it's annoyingly present.
4.) You can pet the Onbu. Give it plenty of pats and have a happy village!

What I didn't like:
1.) Currently, there's no representation of Onbu's [i]trust[/i] that I could find. Maybe it's there and I was just blind, but all I could go by was whether or not Onbu [i]looked[/i] happy or not - this may be by design and if so I may revise if this as a positive.  Again, I don't watch dev videos so this could have already been mentioned.
2.) Camera is very linear. I would like even a 5-degree swing on the camera. Sometimes you just can't click something because there's too much layered in front of it. You will sometimes NEED to cut down your prized trees [spoiler]Mothertrees[/spoiler] to get that thing [spoiler]spore infestation[/spoiler]. 
3.) I can't seem to get Farms to grow out to as far as you can grow plants - my radius is only 2 grid spaces but the plot size can far exceed that. Could just not be in the right climate (even at green productivity), but I've maxed my water storage units and just could not grow a full farm plot. It's not that this was ever a REAL issue - I always had more than enough food. But I would have to build three farms to produce what a single farm could potentially grow.
4.) The way items are stored and the lack of a "placement" sorter. I would like to be able to store specific thing closer to specific buildings or gathering locations. It would be nice to be able to configure what is stored where or some sort of [i]priority[/i] sorting. But this isn't so much as a negative as it's more of a personal want.

Overall, 9/10 - would recommend to anyone wanting to play or thinking of getting this game. It's simple to learn, easy to pick up, and if you're into village sims this game is perfect for you. Absolutely glowing gem of a game.

I am absolutely addicted to this game. It not only has a unique premise but intuitive and rewarding gameplay; furthermore, the player needn't feel "forced" into solving problems a single intended way. The devs have done an excellent job crafting a focused, yet varied experience. I can't wait to see what the devs have in store for this game over the next year or so.

Specifically, I'd like to see the following improvements:
1. Better difficulty pacing. Right now it just seems to ramp up linearly and you just never get a break. Maybe decrease the time that sunny/snowy areas are active or have the game check obstacles in the pervious area before populating new areas with obstacles.
2. More "static" upgrades for buildings or actions in research. You max out research pretty quickly and there's only so much room for new buildings, so increasing the buildings'/actions' effects or offering further specialization will further vary gameplay and give the player more tools to solve problems.
3. More Onbu interactions! I love this big guy and I want to feed him treats and play with him and watch him be a very large silly boi.

I highly recommend this game but one major gripe I have is the price, for what it is currently I think its a bit overpriced so I would recommend waiting for a few updates before reviewing what has changed.

122589682.review:
Man I desperately want to love this game but I only just like it, and its hard for me to recommend for that reason.

The good things are the art design, the sound design, the theme, and for the most part the systems. These are all great, and the idea of a village on the back of a behemoth is super cool for a colony sim management game.

But then you start playing, and after a certain point, things get frustrating. Resource management is important as your village grows, especially the simple In / Out tracking for each resource you generate. I.e. I generate 3 berries a day, and eat 2 berries a day. The game lacks any features to track this information outside of the most broad examples (total food in/out for example, but no breakdown as to what foods are being eaten and in which quantities). This makes managing those parts of the village very annoying.

Secondly, worker tracking is almost nonexistent. You can assign workers to different jobs and buildings, and unemployed workers will supposedly follow the generic orders you give to harvest, build, transport, etc. But there is no broad overview for your worker placement, so when your village grows in pop size, it again becomes extremely tedious trying to figure out where your workers are assigned, which ones can be unassigned, etc. All you can see is a total number of employed vs unemployed, which isn't helpful when you need to make large decisions or rearrange worker assignments on a larger scale.

Third, the task queueing is a mess. There are 4 prio levels - none, low, medium, and high. This is supposed to make it so you can more or less dictate which actions happen first, second, third, fourth. But without an explicit task queue that you can manage, it's difficult to track exactly what workers are going to do before they do something else. This becomes very frustrating when you are dealing with a crisis situation (poisonous plants that spread very quickly and need to be removed ASAP for instance), and your workers just seemingly ignore your high priority tasks for some unknown reason.

I really like the game's aesthetic, I just think it needs some serious QoL features in terms of gameplay before I can actually enjoy it, which is why for now, I can't recommend it.

122568319.review:
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:
It is an interesting and innovative concept for a city builder, and the art direction is top notch. I would like to see deeper game mechanics, as right now the game is shallow in a few areas. You can choose to be symbiotic or parasitic towards Onbu, and the game does not chastise you for picking the latter too much. I can always respect a game that lets me play as a villain. However, it is a bit easy to get on Onbu's good side (he is a sucker for pets) and there are no late game buildings or mechanics for the symbiotic route yet. Parasitic seems to have gotten more attention at the moment.

Recommending for anyone who loves simple city builders or the Ghibli anime movies that inspire the game. Not really recommended for those looking for a deep city builders with lots of options at present; you may get bored easily. This may change as more content is added. I'd love to see this game reach its full potential.

Sometimes the beast is doing well on their own, sometimes you have to help them so you can survive as well, that's the whole point and they nailed that. I also like that Onbu doesn't always listen, it gives me strong The Last Guardian vibes.

That said, the game IS Early Access, so don't expect a complete experience or 0 bugs, but judging from their reaction to our reaction, I think they'll be taking good care of the game. It does feel like a labor of love.

This game is a nice little game if you just want to chill out and have quite an enjoyable ride on a big stupid beast. Because it is really, really stupid. Amicable, but boy is it stupid. But let's start at the beginning:
The game basically drops you with a little background story onto Onbu. Further story has not been implemented yet. So you ride this big doofus and try to make your living while satisfying its frankly quite humble needs.
With a catchy nice soundtrack and decent UI the game is entertaining while new research achievements keep you interested in exploring new options. While this is going on, although you have been the nicest you could ever have been to it, Onbu basically chooses to not obey you in the worst possible situations, running directly through every poison cloud and tornado he can find. It's like it's trying to get rid of you, but you hold on, you keep petting it and hope for the best.
The game is not too hard on easy, but you have to prepare for harder times. With mediocre decisions, you can lose and  poisoned plants can overwhelm you if you are ill prepared or not reacting quick enough. After all, it was not too hard to progress on easy mode and explore the game in its entirety.

Being in early Access, the game has it's flaws. While some production lines seem very unnessessary (Tree Nursery and Forester, you really don't need that much wood), other resources seem extremely hard to get by (for me it was stone, harvesting spikes and deep mining both hurt Onbu which at some point I really stopped caring about since the imbecile dinosaur doesn't listen anyway). The Onbu Constipator seems useless and just a bad tradeoff in comparison to the Energy Booster. The food pump really does not seem to give you any advantage since it's really not that hard to stack food and mushrooms while just flinging the food into it's kisser improves its mood. These are probably easy-to-fix issues.
 
After 10 hours on easy mode I came to the point where I discovered all useful research, built everything I wanted, built the endgame milestone and the game had no further objective other to maybe research everything else. So i did that, 5 more hours went by and i am done having seen everything in the game. While having enjoyed the time, that's a bit too little. But it's early access and there's a roadmap, promising some story, better interaction with Onbu and I am really looking forward to it!

After all, I loved my asinine Onbu (even if it didn't love me) and look forward to play it again when it's a bit more polished, since the gameplay was good and fun!

PS: I love my Onbu, no Onbus were harmed in the making of this review. It's a really retarded lizard, though.

As someone who enjoys the occasional city builder, but doesn't necessarily want something super strategic, this is a great game. It can be a bit of a learning curve at first, but once you get the hang of it, it's quite intuitive. That's not to say it's easy, however- you should expect to fail at least a couple of times. You have to balance the needs of your villagers with the needs of Onbu, which can be tricky in certain situations. But the actual base game works like 98% the way it should, barring a few very minor bugs and other things that can be easily fixed. 

HOWEVER- if you're looking to play this game and get a good story out of it, that part hasn't been implemented yet. 122521607.review:
I am torn on this game like other reviewers. It is kind of expensive, it took me 10 hours to play, NOT rushing, and I was mostly repeating the same experience I had 1 hour in. 

For some reason a recent development with games, that they have a wonderful idea, and world, but they feel like a little snapshot with no lasting gameplay. That are just atmospheric and artsy get the mind going but ultimately just seem to provide an empty base for fans to imagine more upon rather then a fulfilling game.
Well it's quite laid back but there's just not enough for a construction sim or make-your-village-perfect type play. And there aren't many events and there really aren't many onbu animations or other interactions for it to be more action oriented either.

-No story mode. 
I think my biggest let-down feeling is there's sort of a lack of lore. In fact I built a monument and the elder popped up and said THX 4 PLAYING EARLY ACCESS, talk about breaking my bubble of immersion. I thought if I was going on it'd get harder as I went, that was the feeling I was getting anyway, and that survival would be rewarded by finding out a linear story. There wasn't any, and the game has low value to time played.

-Low worldbuilding (Some spoilers)
There's not much interaction with your lil guys, you don't get to see any different outfits and art of them or pictures of them doing their adventures when you send them scavenging. Lots of potential for it to be so cinematic and feel like I'm playing Nausicaa or witnessing an epic. Also every "secret" I come across is vaguely onbu related, what about other creatures and worldbuilding? It's more like somebody said "hmm what's in this world.. oh yeah, onbu, that's it".
I love the elder's design with his lil beard coming out of the mask, I would love so much to see more character, learn more, see them develop vehicles, know if they go scouting with gliders or something, or even have more land on the onbu's back, encounter more interesting other groups of people, you know what I mean. Scout tower was even unimpressive, it's not really taller then some of the other buildings. Maybe push their alternate world tech further..
Not really any moral choices, gain nothing really from saving extra people etc, people don't have events or do anything interactive or just unique either. They're not really simulated people. You could be totally evil and nothing would happen except maybe the onbu is a bit mad. No options to choose to try enslave it, or commune with it (Just make it happy, it doesn't speak or have any spiritual significance beyond what you pretend to give it.). No villager thoughts, births, marriages, celebrations, you know. They don't do anything funny or random or cool or atmospheric like Rimworld or other games you might imagine them similar to.

That said I do enjoy it but similar game that came out and I had the same issues with, atleast had much more content to burn through/collect then this one and a more cohesive aesthetic vibe with more music and cutscenes and variety of graphics... so it's kind of an in-between recommendation from me. I waited sooo long for this game, I was so excited and I want so hard to support them and like this! But there isn't even a lot on the roadmap and it was all stretch goals.

The short;
No reason to hate it, love the idea, get it! But don't expect much bang for buck. It isn't buggy but still lacking a lot of content, character or story. Feels a bit more like a "what-if I just watched nausicaa and wanted to make some art about it".

122486004.review:
***The Good***
Concept: Limited-scale city builder played on three layers. 1.) the village, 2.) the onbu, 3.) Interactions with the wider world (onbu's path / biomes / events / scavenging locations)

Art Style: The little 2d animated sprites are adorable, especially because you can zoom down into the village level. Gives it all kind of a whimsical paper-doll look amid the 3d rendering of Onbu itself. The art style was what caught my interest first.

Ongoing Development: Early access games get a bad rap sometimes, I think. This game has a great dev team, and a solid roadmap. I believe that when it's finished, it will be fully worth its price tag.

***The Meh***
Story: Currently nonexistent. There's a little lorebook that explains game mechanics, but no real depth at this stage in development. (More story is planned, however)

Gameplay: Honestly? It's a little thin. Solid for what it is, but once you've figured out a decent priority system, it only takes 1-2 hours to really get rolling. Many colony sims have an early-mid-lategame staging for development, but right now The Wandering Village kind of goes from early to done. There's no real 'endgame.' I hit a point where I had no interest in further research because using the buildings would hurt trust with Onbu, and I was able to survive just fine without them. THAT SAID -- the devs are very communicative, with a clear roadmap.

***Pricing Fairness***
At this stage of development, I probably would have priced this at $20 max, not $25, but bellyaching over $5 on what is clearly a labor of love with a great team behind it seems silly. It's a bit steep but nowhere near robbery. Kind of nice to have a little game like this to boot up now and then.

122481598.review:
I'm honestly a bit torn on this game.

First of all, it's quite fun to play. The mechanic to basically keep your mount "alive" is interesting, there's a lot of different buildings you can utilize and the "world map" feature in which you can basically send out scavenger squads to harvest resources (like in frostpunk, for example) is good and fun and. The building system is also quite simple and not very complex, which might be a plus for many people, personally, I'd prefer a little bit more depth.

I did have a lot of fun with the game, but there's also major gripes:

First of all, while the "keep your mount alive" part is interesting, it's also unnecessary - you have to feed the thing once every 30 minutes and that's it. I've build the doctor hut for it and not once did I have to use it besides healing a poison once, and I could've just not done that. It's a badly balanced mechanic that doesn't really serve any purpose and just occupies a handful of villagers, you have to manually turn the buildings on and off to free them so they can do something more useful.

Second, the graphics. While they are not bad by any means and the creature you're riding on is gorgeous, the village and the villager itself are all 2D and this vastly downgrades the visual fidelity. I don't know why they made the decision to create the game in 2D - potentially because of a small team and not enough resources to create a 3D or at least 2.5D game, but it's a major factor that really rubs me the wrong way.

The last problem is simple - content. You can finish a run in about 3 - 4 hours. Your last task is to build a big statue that costs a few advanced resources (which you should honestly have at the end of the run) and then it basically transforms into endless mode. The problem is that every run feels roughly the same. The map doesn't change, the biomes don't change - you start the same way every time and there is no variety. That's vastly different in other games in the genre - again, I use frostpunk as example. Frostpunk has edicts, so you can alter the ideology of your town. You can be a highly christian authoritarian that basically creates the nazi-vatican that forces children to work in coal mines or you can become the benevolent mayor of your little ice city. Also, there is a variety of maps in the game, so every playthrough is different. This is completely missing in the wandering village. It's just the same run over and over again.

Overall, I think the game is a bit lacking and the only reason why I'm recommending this is because it's still early access. I have high hopes for the game and if the devs pull the right strings, they could easiely make a great game ouf of this.

I did love the option to keep my villagers and Onbu from dying, because that happened to me a lot in the demo. I look forward to all that the dev team is going to do fro this game.

The game has a nice feel to it with a beautiful art style and presentation. The devs were clearly inspired by Frostpunk as well, with a decision system similar and ruthless death of villagers similar to that game. However while decisions matter in Frostpunk, here they just don't. It is always correct to accept more villagers and when I got half of them killed because we ran out of food there were no consequences. 122474795.review:
The Wandering Village is a Colony Sim Roguelike where each run is random. The way Onbu chooses to go, the map, the events, and the layout for the top of Onbu will all be different. When you start a run, you get to choose from three difficulties. Bringing me to my first tip, choose novice if you are unfamiliar with colony simulators.

This is a fun game, but it can be challenging. Poison sucks. It spreads quickly, and you need to get rid of it fast. There is a way to stop the spread, but you must research the necessary things first. My second tip is to start researching as soon as possible. There are three categories to research: Village, Resources, and Onbu. The more you play, the easier the game will seem.

My third tip is to pay attention to your colony and Onbu. My first and second runs ended because I paid attention to the poison spreading on Onbu too much. I thought that my first run would end because of the poison spreading causing all of my villagers to die, but it did not end that way. My second run felt a lot easier than the first run.

I also tested this game on the Steam Deck, which works and looks great. Many. if not all, of the controls, are already configured to work with the Steam Deck. The touchpad and all of the buttons do something in-game. If you choose to play this on Steam Deck, you will have to play around with the game to get a feel for it, but then you should have a good time.

My last tip is to follow the directions on the right side of the game. It will teach you how to play and advise you on what to do. This is not a tip, but I like to start by setting up a road from the start of Onbu to the front.

Overall, this game is fun challenging Colony Sim Roguelike. The visuals and artwork are great. You can zoom in on the map and see the village in its full glory, which is one of the coolest things in this game. It is also in Early Access, and I expect the game to get better.

Find more reviews from me on my Steam curator page:
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41065644-Jimi-Reviews-Games/

Find more Steam Deck reviews from me on my Steam Deck curator page:
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42800057-TreeofEmber/

Here is the YouTube video of my first impressions of the game:
https://youtu.be/_pfCchR2f38

122471096.review:
TLDR: A unique game that blends some of the interesting decisions of similar colony/survival games with some unexpected and interesting themes. Worth the price of admission at this time but will be curious how the developers manage to provide a lengthier experience having more or less shown their cards at this stage in a ~10 hour experience.

I think this game has some great ideas and I was quite entertained until the end. It's in early access but it hardly trips over itself at all and, importantly for me, it's very easy to just open and play without needing to go find youtube tutorials or anything. Gameplay wise I thought it was a fun mix of frost punk and other colony management/survival games like rimworld. There are some interesting ethical situations that feel akin to some aspects of the child labour frost punk narratives: unfortunately I never felt like I was forced to make any truly hard decisions or compromises  as the game seems to pull it's punches and provide alternative mechanics which allow the player to just avoid these entirely.

Having said that, there are some decently interesting decisions that you have to make and the process of balancing 3-4 different systems triggered that colony sim enjoyment part of my brain.  I'm not sure how much they could add to lengthen the game experience and have it be different enough to be interesting so I'm curious how feature-full it is at present vs their vision of the end product. Overall I'd say it's worth a buy and playthrough if you enjoy games in this space.

Players with a deep background of playing colony sim games who are curious about innovation in the genre will have an enjoyable experience but are unlikely to replay this. Those who are new to these games may find more mystery in the systems and could potentially get a lot more from the game as it does a very good job of initiating those new to it's peers.

122459757.review:
This is a great city management game with other game aspects sprinkled in. You manage your people, resources and buildings like many other city builders...but in this game the very land you live upon is alive and must also be tended to. Your living vessel named Onbu must be taken care of; he has a health bar, can be poisoned and it gets tired and requires rest. As such you have a symbiotic relationship with your host and you can perform actions such as mining giant rock spikes to gain stone, at the cost of hurting Onbu, thus lowering its trust in you. If Onbu has high trust in you then you are able to give it commands, telling it to walk, run, sleep and more. This is beneficial in many cases, especially if you need to get through a dangerous area quickly.

There are currently several biomes with more planned to be added. Biomes affect many things including crop growth/decay speed, humidity (for water generation), poison level and more. It can be challenging pivoting between which type of crops you are growing and how you obtain food & water based on your current biome.

There is a researchable skill tree that is currently modest but will surely grow as this game is in early access. 

Another feature I like is you can create a scavenging team that will visit more distant POIs and can acquire resources for the city. This also sometimes allows for "side quests" where you get to choose from a list of options that can affect the outcome and resources gained.

Currently I have a little over 12 hours into the game so far and have not seen a single bug. 

All in all this is a very well made game and you can see the love that has been and continues to be put into it. 5/5 from me, as far as an early access game goes. At this point I feel like I am very near end-game so I look forward to more content as the game develops!

122447726.review:
Really neat idea for a management game! Having to take care of Onbu as well as your villagers puts an interesting twist into gameplay. 

Pros:
I really enjoyed the toxic plants effect, since it can get out of control very quickly and requires you to make quick, sweeping decisions to control the spread of the infection. Things can get very harrowing very quickly depending on how unlucky you are - I had a toxic plants effect then an earthquake right afterward in the early game which was definitely a fun challenge to recover from. I also never ran into any bugs or performance issues, and the art style is absolutely beautiful and unique.

Cons:
My biggest gripe is that the game could use some balancing. I played on the hardest difficulty and never really had too many issues. The hardest part of the game is getting established within the first 1 - 2 hours. Once you build a couple decontaminators + blie extractor, and get Onbu to like you enough to always listen to your commands, then the game gets pretty easy. Berry collectors/farms are ridiculously productive and I never felt like I was desperate enough to harvest blood or do anything to make Onbu lose trust in my decisions. To challenge myself, I just completely stopped using the hornblower because being able to fully control Onbu's actions is just too OP right now. There's also some sound issues - I noticed that the background music will sometimes just end abruptly rather than smoothly transitioning when you move into a different biome.

Conclusion:
Overall a really unique, well put-together game with a ton of potential. Since the game is early access I'm definitely willing to forgive some of the balance issues, as I'm sure they'll get ironed out.

122447048.review: I absolutely love this game and so very addicted to it!  The ONLY complaint I have is that it actually takes two workers to first chop/pickaxe stone and wood and then another to actually pick it up to take it to storage.  So it takes a bit for you to get materials.  Other than that my only frustration is keeping poor Onbu fed!

122446374.review:
I myself have played far too many city-builder survival games, like FrostPunk, Rimworld, Dawn of Man, Clanfolk, etc. After a while these games start to feel the same in many ways, they start becoming tedious and usually it becomes like playing the same game with a different skin, at least for me. So you can imagine my initial apprehension to The Wandering Village, but I was tempted by the truly unique mechanic of having to coexist with a giant beast for your colony to flourish. I tell you now I was not disappointed. 

I began my first playthrough focusing entirely on industrial colony growth, the Onbu's needs became secondary and initially I had no problems with that. However, as the game progressed and I began exploring new biomes, it very quickly became apparent that the Onbu directly and indirectly affected the growth, quality and difficulty I encountered with my colony. At around day 50 my colony was lost to a massive infestation of poison plants despite dedicating most of my colony to decontamination. During my second playthrough I focused on Onbu-related buildings and by day 50 I had a flourishing colony. 

I've noticed that Onbu trust and overall happiness seems to directly affect the events your colony encounters, I noticed during my first playthrough I had knocked out a few of the Onbu spikes (sorry buddy) and the Onbu seemed borderline suicidal, meaning that it had skipped over a poison-free sleep spot despite being half full on the tired meter. The difference is subtle but vitally make a difference for your colony. 

This mechanic is well-designed and well-implemented despite the cheeky difficulty change. I quite like it overall, it is a breath of fresh air compared to other colony sims. It is much more engaging to me than say Rimworld.

Coming back to the game after a few months and with all the updates, tweaks, fixes and improvements that have been made my initial reaction still holds true. I do believe this is a solid pickup of a game for anyone who enjoys city builders or resource management style games.

122429487.review:
This is a wonderfully atmospheric and accessible city-builder where you juggle the needs of your growing village with the usual - managing food, water, housing, health etc - as well as the needs of your enormous animal host, Onbu. 

The game sells this symbiosis well, with Onbu moving you onwards from biome to biome; bringing you access to new resources and temperatures, which determine which crops you can grow, the scarcity of water, and the toxicity-levels from (the presumably apocalyptic amounts of) pollution that has reduced the world to the smattering of ruins and nomad tribes left for you to encounter throughout the game.  

If you like the atmosphere in [i]Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind[/i], then its heavy influence on this game's design will light a fire in you.

It is well fleshed-out for an Early-Access title, with integrated facility to provide feedback and bug-reports in-game.  Its early-access launch content was enough to keep me entertained for a solid week or so, and I can see that growing exponentially as the game increases in complexity with the addition of new biomes, events, stories, and goals.  I'm excited to see the project grow, and to check-back after launch to see what's been added!

122428761.review:
It's a fun colony sim with an interesting twist. Your settlement is on top of Onbu, a massive dog-like creature that walks around the world aimlessly. It'll wander into various biomes that introduce climate related challenges and hazards to overcome. Not only do you need to tend to the needs of your people, but also your companion Onbu that you can interact with a bit. 

I recommend the game in it's current state; it's very polished for an early access game. Do keep in mind however that it's a fairly short experience. In the 12 or so hours that I played I managed to 'beat' the game and have done just about everything there is too do. It's also not a very complex game; don't expect too difficult of a ride if you are somewhat decent at micromanagement. I am looking forward to see what else the developers are going to do with this title. 

Is it worth the price? It may be a bit steep, but I don't consider it much of an issue. I feel it's important to support the developers so they can spend more time on developing the game. It's not the biggest genre out there, so every little bit helps it stay alive.

122415255.review:
A good but forgettable city builder (in its current state).

First of all, the game has good art design. The villagers and architecture really adds to the world-building of the game, reminds me a bit of Nausica from Studio Ghibli. The diorama-like presentation gives a unique and easy-to-look-at perspective when playing the game.

Now, as a city builder, the game isn't much different from other city builders aside from the travelling titan (Onbu) that you rely on to live. The research tree is bare bones and the world map doesn't have much to it which should be a point of emphasis since the travelling Onbu is the selling point of this game.

But I did enjoy my 17 hours in game. Achieving 100 days and 100 pop after a couple tries and restarts after understanding the mechanics better. The graphics are eye candy and pace of progression is great unlike other city builders/resource management games that tend to just snowball during late-game.

Overall 7.5/10. I think the game still has room to grow but I'm keeping my expectations for early access low.

Just an idea for devs if you see this. It's a long shot but make an End Game that has the villagers seek out a "paradise" in a treasure hunt-style system. Like the movie Wall-E or Waterworld where the characters must find habitable land in a post-apocalyptic world. But this would require a big overhaul to the map instead of being just North-South. The Onbu could also backtrack it's path so the player might have to run around in circles. The map should be big enough that the player doesn't accidentally just stumble upon the paradise. There should also be clues around the map that scavengers could seek out and a cartography system to document the path the player has taken. Like a said, a long shot but I think this would be my dream version of this game. Also veteran is too easy. Cheers!

122411389.review:
So far, the game has a TON of promise, if the devs continue to update this game in the near future with simple patches and new content. This game has the makings to be one of the cutest and most unique resource managements games of all time. Its still in early access so there is deffinitly some kinks to work out. 

Positives:
Art style is cute and fun
Concept is well done 
UI is well made and easy to use
Easy to sink hours into 
Decent challenge late game

Negatives:
Not much change in gameplay loop overtime so can be repetitive 
Some mechanics of the game (such as the workers post) need a more in depth explanation
It is VERY easy to lose by making simple mistakes in early game
Some mechanics don't work on occasion (I had full water storage and no one was bringing water to any farms, and so nothing would be planted, no matter what my workers post was assigned to nor how many unemployed villagers I had)
Price is a little steep at the moment for how much content the game actually has long term. Get it on sale for a around 20$ if you can later when more updates come out. 

Overall: 
I do recommend this game, it has a very interesting concept, a fun art style and gameplay with just enough complexity to make it worthwhile to do a proper playthrough of. But the lack of late game content does leave me wishing for more to do. I've kept my eye on this game for a little while now and I look forward to the updates Stray Fawn plan for it. I feel for now I'm going to continue to check up on this game from time to time to see what changes are made. But it won't be something I come back and play frequently. For now anyway. I can see that easily changing depending on how the development continues.

I adore the idea of moving cities, and this one is just a treat. Taking care of Onbu is such a unique and fun mechanic. The city building aspect excels at early to mid gameplay; however, the late game brings many issues.

I generally like micromanaging games. However, I'm not too fond of repetitive micromanagement. The late-game of The Wandering Village is generally that. I send the explorers, check correct crops, update kitchen recipes, and repeat. Sometimes I build something new, which is exciting, but other than that, it is a repetitive loop. Sometimes Onbu encounters events. They are fun at first. At the late game, it is just another micromanagement. Turn off some buildings, turn on flamethrowers, wait, revert, and continue my micromanagement loop. The further your village progresses, the worse the repetitive micromanagement is because you have to switch more buildings. This game desperately needs some endgame QoL or automation and offer some new endgame non-repetitive activities.

Final update: Finished 3rd game at veteran level in 8 hrs. Significantly harder in every way. Almost died several times. I will still recommend this game but it does need more content for me to play anymore. 

Update: Finished a 2nd game at medium level in 7 hours. Nothing new content wise just slightly harsher weather at higher difficulty.  Built a watch tower this game and wow! MUCH bigger range to send scouting parties. Had to build three scouting parties to keep up because range is so big. Collected all sand and mines from scouts and building monument was easy. Much easier 2nd time through with the learning curve over .. even at higher difficulty.

Initial impressions: It's an ok game for early access. Hope this game keeps improving.  Do not regret buying it.  Built a monument which I consider "winning the game" within 14 hrs at beginner level. It's basically a research and resource gathering and allocating your workers game (wood, stone, food, etc). The twist with the game is that you are on top of a moving beast so your environment keeps changing (temp, water, poison). Once you figure out what buildings and workers do what it's not a hard game. If you prep for what you see coming there are no big surprises ... like run through the poison clouds and tornado areas so they ain't so bad.  Placing  buildings for efficiency so workers do not have to walk too far seems important in this game. Try and build up good stockpiles of water and food early to get you through the leaner times. Being able to control your ride becomes more and more important later in game (run, sleep, north or south). There is a little lag in giving orders and when the workers get around to doing what you want so you have to be planning ahead a little. I found issuing too many harvest or build commands at same time seemed to bog things down. Using work priority levels helped. Only compliant I have is sometimes I had to do some micro management (click specific things and bump up the priority) and that got a little tedious.

Cons:
- If you don't like soup you might have a problem - there's no other type of food the kitchen can make
- no goal besides "survive as long as you can" (at least as far as I've gotten).

122384897.review:
Cute premise, beautiful art, extremely unbalanced and punishing.

Not a single element of this game's city construction and management is sustainable. When accounting for water production (which is a whole other farm most of the time) a single farm can't sustain the workers it takes to tend it.  The temperature change so frequently that you have to change your farms produce constantly and the AI doesn't rotate crops so you end up deadlocked in non-productive land. The decontamintor building can't clear the city before you run into another poison cloud and the problem gets worse, and the onbu's health/poison meters fill so quickly it takes at least half your already unsufficient resources to keep it struggling along.

If this team hires a competent excel monkey to make play sustainable in literally any fashion I'd say it's worth considering, but as it stands this is a parody of a city builder, and the joke is on you for playing it.

122384664.review:
I absolutely love this game. All mecanics are amazing, and it is a pleasure to cooperate with the giant you are riding once you are friendly enough. Managing your food sources, depending on what kind of land you're going through, is simple enough that it won't destroy your game if you forget to immediatly switch from beets to corn, but important enough for you to feel the need of your people to eat. The toxic jungles are really dangerous but manageable, especially once you can ask your giant to run through it. This game is a gem, and I'm really happy for getting it.

All of that being said, it is still in early access, and I really hope the team is gonna add some features. One of them being : the auto save (or at least, the choice for the player to play with autosave). Currently, you can only save manualy, and given how deeply the game takes you, you WILL forget to save your game. And that's how I reached 800 km, discovering my first big toxic forest, followed immediatly by a small one. I didn't think much of it at first, and just thought "well, buddy will run through it and everything will be fine". but I forgot to check how tired he was, and... well, long story short, he fell asleep in the second forest. and no matter how friendly you are, if your giant is exhausted, you can't ask him to get up to keep walking. So I could only watch as my entire map was getting ravaged by toxic plants. and that was the end of my first game. My previous save was back into tutorial...

So of course, my bad. But I really think that an auto save, even if it is every 20 minutes, would really benefit this game.

122384251.review:
I want to start by saying: it is a good game.

TL;DR: solid game, not enough content at this price. Details below.

The Wandering Village is still in early access and for such a game it feels remarkably fleshed out. Apart from some minor quality-of-life problems, the game feels solid and well-made. The art style is charming and unique, the music is fitting and even engaging at places, the UI is easy to navigate and on top of all that, I see some refreshing novel ideas I haven't encountered before. It is clear to me that a lot of love has gone into the making of this game.

Overall, The Wandering Village has a really solid foundation upon which the developers can build.

Why the negative review? The price. 
There's simply not enough content for €22,49 at this moment.
There is no story or campaign to speak of, which is fine, considering this is a city-builder/management game but all the other parts of the game are also lacking in content.

In less than 10 hours you can experience everything the game has to offer. 
In this timeframe I have researched everything, built everything, deliberately navigated Onbu into every possible negative effect I could find, I sent my Scavangers to everything on the map and I even purposefully tested what happens to Onbu if the hunger meter is at max or what happens when I purposefully deplete his life.

For half the price - or with more content added - I would absolutely recommend this game.

122376713.review:
I don't think I've spent more time on a game demo. Literally more time than on some "AAA" games. Even did the playtest and now the Early Access version.
-----
It's dangerous out there! Take your entire village along. On this roadtrip, take your fellow villagers and see to the needs and happiness of your gigantic ride. Hot and cold, dry and wet, disease and poisons... trouble is coming and you have to build and manage your village even as it's being carried past varied biomes and unfriendly weather. Harvest, craft and build a new village. Feed and pet the only livestock you'll ever need.
-----
An entirely pacifistic, time-critical management game. Don't forget to pickup after your pet ^_^ 

The aesthetics is a cutesy 2D/parallax style reminiscent of some better animation, complete with a soundtrack that's moody, rousing or anxious as the situation befits

Gameplay revolves around your 'ride'. Not only must you acquire resources, craft and build infrastructure like most city-sims, you have to take care of your 'ride' as well. Or it'll start to sulk and decide to sleep in a giant cloud of toxins or get so riled up, you get 'earthquakes'. Plus all those villagers... need food and shelter as well. Assign jobs to them and navigate your ride through deserts, jungles and more. Discover and progress through a tech-tree and cope with unnatural disasters. Pick up your ride's poop too.

If I had to compare to other games... I'd call it a rogue-lite city-builder, heavy on the RNG.

Update: New features have been updated, numerous QOL additions as well as fixes. Ocean biome released plus one more new biome to come and more. The game keeps getting bigger, better.
